Title: All I want for Xmas are toddler books featuring non white characters
Message:
When slightly older, please get Ada Twist scientist! We love that book.

In the meantime,  it's depressingly hard but these are some of the best matches I found: 
[[Waiting for baby [[https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1846432758/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?linkCode=as2&linkId=832cf9d6eb681f76973a06dbafeb70dd&creativeASIN=1846432758&ref_=d6k_applink_bb_marketplac&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8&creative=9325]]e]]
[[What's in there? [[https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0763636304/ref=as_li_qf_asin_il_tl?linkCode=as2&linkId=b9f85a55d15598735b23f5d8f0d340ee&creativeASIN=0763636304&ref_=d6k_applink_bb_marketplac&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8&creative=9325]]e]]
[[You can do it too [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/You-Can-Too-Karen-Baicker/dp/081187561X/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=you+can+do+it+too&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607155843&sr=8-]]1]]
Maybe Lola reads to Leo?

Some of these are showing longer delivery times on amazon. I would recommend calling your local independent bookshop with a list if the books you want, they can normally get books with a few days - much faster than amazon.

Also, if you can go your local independent bookshop or library and browse I would bet money they have a better choice than online as trained librarians and book sellers are often much more conscious about trying to provide a balanced selection of books than online sellers.

There are a few- some with white and some with black children as main character- I think they are nice as a set as you get the mix. Also showing empowerment at a very basic level.

My husband is mixed race and I am white- our boys 'look' white but have a back grandparent and black cousins so it's so important to us that characters they are exposed to replicate their family.

Title: Where can I start to find out more about nutrition for a vegan family?
Message:
If you need info about vegan nutrition, you start with a nutrition book and the best is without a doubt this one Becoming Vegan: Comprehensive Edition: The Complete Reference on Plant-based Nutrition  
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Becoming-Vegan-Comprehensive-Reference-Plant-based/dp/1570672970?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] 

Givent the complexity of each of your needs, I am not sure how you can make this work in a healthy way. 
Low fibre - high calories is quite in contradiction with a VEGan diet, unless you abandon whole food and go for crappy vegan junk food, such as vegan cheeses, vegan Frankenstein meat substitute and so on.  Plants have fibre, animals have bones. Unless you use processed grains (white flour, white rice, ...) you will have fibre. Plants are low calories Animal products (cheese, butter, cream, ....) are high calories.  Of course, you have avocado, seeds and nuts, but they are not low fibre. 

Losing weight is quite easy if you stick to the VEG part of vegan, but the soya allergy makes it quite complicated as tofu is a very versatile part for feeding children. 

IN addition to educating yourself on vegan nutrition and which supplement you MUST take , use cronometer.com to see if your nutritional needs are covered. It will give you the numbers for all macro and micronutrients for free. 

You need to understand that the vitamin and mineral in a food isn't the amount your body will be able to use, or absorb. In the case of plant based omega 3, the conversion rate is around 5% so it is very very hard to get your omega 3 from planets . You then have the oxalate in plants that block calcium, and so on. 

Malnutrition is rampant amongst vegan. Many have a 50-shades-of-beige diet. 

Any reason you are considering a vegan diet with low fibre - soya allergy?

Title: Recommendations for drawing tablet for 13 yr old budding artist?
Message:

She has it connected to her MacBook because it has no display and it shows in the screen. Sheâ€™s using it a lot for photoshop for her gcse photography as well as art work.

Title: Weaning
Message:
You first need to understand how swallowing works and that is very different from sucking, even from a pouch 
When you suck, the food/liquid is pushed against the roof of the mouth, the palate and from there it goes down. When eating a puree, but even a liquid such as a soup, the tongue needs to push the food towards the back of the mouth and then down. It will take several days to understand this process, so if the food comes out instead of going down , it is absolutely normal. 
Then, you need to make it liquidy until baby figures out he needs to chew. Chewing will produce saliva which will help lubricate the food and let it slide down the throat. Image your self taking a mouthful of mashed potatoes and swallowing without chewing  even once , it will get stuck. But if covered in sauce, far more easy. 

So the first times, prepare your cut veggies this way: cook them in a small pot in 3 cm water at the bottom and let them simmer for 15-20 min, then blend them with whatever liquid is left at the bottom. If during cooking process, too much water evaporates , add more, if too much water is left, remove veggies and add spoonful of water one by one. Blend. 
In France, first food is soup pumpkin soup, pea soup, mix veggies soup and so on. You can then add a bit of parmesan cheese to make it tasty. 
Some baby pasta is no bigger than a pencil dot, and go can make a rich broth and then cook the pasta like this one [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Ghigi-Italian-Pasta-Tempestina-500/dp/B0872JMM56/ref=pd_lpo_325_t_0/261-9090437-3534048?psc=1&pf_rd_p=7b8e3b03-1439-4489-abd4-4a138cf4eca6&_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_wg=lLrKK&pf_rd_r=QTBMK7Q33371S2H1MAFK&pd_rd_i=B0872JMM56&pd_rd_w=5Sfau&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&refRID=QTBMK7Q33371S2H1MAFK&pd_rd_r=2fa7d957-d36c-4bcf-afe2-b0322b6c314c]] in it. 

Plenty of time for finger food, encourage real food, real taste, and careful with  the baby porridge , it is often very sweet. Normal porridge, left soaked overnight is fine, and if you want to sweeten it , make your own apple sauce.

Title: Living with Fibromyalgia
Message:
I totally understand. I used to be fit and active -ran, did weights, yoga so exercised 6 days a week-suddenly unable to get off the sofa and eventually diagnosed with CFS and then later also fibromyalgia. Itâ€™s been 5 years now & I was just over 40 when I was diagnosed. Sorry if this is long and rambling. My brain doesnâ€™t have the clarity it used to! 

Until I was prescribed gabapentin (which I resisted taking for several months as I was worried about side effects) I used to spend all night rolling from one side of the bed to the other, because even lying in one position would cause so much pain, & DH had moved into the spare room.

I now at least get some sleep and it does help with the pain but I do struggle to work my 20 hours a week, I get home and canâ€™t move off the sofa. I have no life basically. In fact having everything closed is almost a relief because at least now I donâ€™t have to worry that the neighbours are wondering why I never leave the house or do anything.

I did read that eating gluten free relieved symptoms, maybe it does as there are some days when I feel less awful and the pain is certainly less than it was when it first all started.

I also try to pace myself when not at work as I was forever, if I was having a good day, trying to cram all the things in that I couldnâ€™t do on a bad day and end up using all my spoons and then not having enough to get through the next day.
[[https://www.practicalpainmanagement.com/patient/resources/pain-self-management/using-spoon-theory-explain-chronic-pain]]

Itâ€™s hard and the first few years were really bad. I was miserable and very much thinking that my life is over, why me? I think stressing about it caused constant flare ups... which meant more pain ...which caused more stress..... I think gaining a level of acceptance really helped, as did giving up alcohol, I do now even manage to do short yoga sessions on my days off and do feel better just being able to do this for me.
There are times I even manage a walk but not very often I must admit. I am lucky that DH mostly does the hoovering as that leaves me exhausted and in pain but I now have learnt just not to stress if the place does need hoovering because jumping up and doing it could leave me feeling so awful. It can just wait until DH is free.

[[https://youtu.be/BFaXfQpxnps]]

I also ended up with low B12 and now have injections 12 weekly to keep my levels topped up and Iâ€™m on prescription vitamin D  due to deficiencies. There are some small studies that suggest links between low B12 & fibromyalgia and also that Vitamin D can help fibro suffers but the â€˜normal rangeâ€™ for B12 in the U.K. is set very low. In Germany people can buy B12 for self injection in the chemists but we can only get a prescription (although you can seemingly ship it over to the U.K. and self inject if you are desperate. There were some links on a MN thread Iâ€™m sure you could search for if need be)

I also use this at night, 3 pumps of lotion after my shower. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/BetterYou-Magnesium-Body-Lotion-180ml/dp/B00U6CG5QU?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Low magnesium causes sleeplessness and muscle pain, I feel it helps. Some studies say magnesium helps people with fibromyalgia, others say it makes no difference but when you are desperate you try anything & if it works for me I donâ€™t really care if itâ€™s placebo tbh. 

If I can think of anything else I will pop back on tomorrow. Itâ€™s pretty much bedtime as Iâ€™m exhausted as per usual towards the end of the week.

Title: Support thread for those experiencing or recently experienced a MC/MMC
Message:
I only paid Â£4.50 for my method one. Here is the link:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07LGS5V1Y/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_9RVaGbXCGNAQ8?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Well I cook most dinners so he will have whatever I make. He is okay to eat more fish etc. Cereal is actually high in folate so I'm leaving him alone on that one. His diet is generally good so with he vitamins I'm hoping that is enough. He is about to be the wrong side of 35 too though so I might start getting more on his back ðŸ˜‚ 
We are trying to be really good Monday to Thursday, naughty Fridays, and okayish Saturdays and Sundays. I have been drinking some wine at weekends but I'm gonna stop after tomorrow I think and only drink when I'm on my period or before I ovulate to be 100% sure I'm definitely not pregnant! 
I've bought some Quorn food as that is a great source of protein too! 

 yeah absolutely I'm having loads of Spanish, broccoli and scouts each day to get my folate intake as well!

Title: Support thread for those experiencing or recently experienced a MC/MMC
Message:
I would personally either you a First Response Early Reponse which is 6ml/u or buy some cheaper more sensitive ones. I got these, then when these go negative will test with the First Response 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0026RQ75W/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_Mul9FbBZYWFP1?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

The issue if you don't get a complete negative one is you can't be sure if any lines in future are leftover tissue from this pregnancy or a new pregnancy. So personally would advise getting a bit know sensitive xx

Title: Support thread for those experiencing or recently experienced a MC/MMC
Message:
so on products it basically says try and use fragrance free and plant based. I don't wear make up now I'm WFH all the time. I do use fragrance body wash but again I'm only making significant changes so for me I'll not going to take it too far. I have bought Method cleaning products though to avoid using harsh bleach as I am forever using Flash to clean my kitchen! So that is plant based. But again, I'm only using that for my kitchen which I clean daily. For the bathroom and things I clean weekly I'm using normal cleaning products 

The biggest thing for over 35s in the group was ubiquinol. She strongly suggests (as do others and the podcast  suggested) 400mg. I got these ones from amazon. I'm only taking 200mg at the moment but might up the dose

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0716Q35T1/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_s4X7FbBH5TDSD?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

It is really tough. Hopefully you're little girl brings you some comfort. You are definitely not too late, but it does make it harder. But remember harder doesn't mean impossible xx

Title: Small dinner plates
Message:
Help!

We're trying to lose weight as a family but the giant white IKEA plates make the portions look so tiny. They're not. There's enough food, but it just looks so disappointing. My mum's gradually built up a collection of little European style plates. (I'm no good with visualising dimensions). But she got hers in dribs and drabs via charity shops. 

I want a size between standard side and dinner plate and pretty, rather than white. With ideally matching bits and not stupidly expensive.  Found some lovely ones on Amazon but Â£75 for 5 plates!

Can anyone help?

Title: What are you wearing today? Autumn 2020
Message:
Chucking it down here still and most of our access roads are closed apparently so maybe a quiet day!

 was it you who asked about hair? When I lost my hair due to chemo I had weird regrowth and went to a specialist chemo hairdresser ( Toni and guy have this service in big towns, had to go a long way) and she recommended baby shampoo to start and then Aveda damage remedy shampoo and conditioner ( which they didn't sell). Then I used a gentle l'occitane range and now I switch between this two and sometimes use this [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00EM6CK1K/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 TRESeme]] conditioner.  My hair is in pretty good condition now although I still have the baby hair at my temples which I've learned to live with. DD had the same issue with regrowth after chemo three years ago and we just used baby shampoo when we could wash her hair. Her hair is now curly ( was strong wave like me) and we try to do curly girl but uts far too tricky for her and me to manage with her just in bed!

Too: Boden
Dungarees: fatface
Trainers: vans
Cardigan: sezane

Title: can anyone suggest a nice flask / bottle for drinking milk in for an adult?
Message:
I know this! I have a son that has needs whole milk for health reasons!

Anything  with less moving parts and simple  opening  work best. 

Depending  on if you want something  pretty and bottle looking, steel vacuum flask water bottles are good. You may have to stick them in a sleeve with a cool pack in the heat of summer. Thermos vacuum water bottles and fab all year round  and a bit more compact if you can find one. 

But actually  [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B077TW8H8W/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_2fFYFbSZY68SF?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Built flasks]] are the best. No moving parts or fiddly bits so far easier to clean. Its Solid and the vacuum  is good enough to keep whole milk in a heat wave mid summer. Contigo arent reliable  enough for cold. Thermos are awesome but not quite as easy to clean.

The house can be cleaned later.

Tile Essentials (2020) Bluetooth Item Finder Set - 4 Pack (2 Stickers, 1 Mate, 1 Slim). Works with Alexa and Google Smart Home. iOS and Android Compatible. Find your Keys, Wallets, Remotes & More. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R api]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R fabc]]c_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07W86T94T/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_dvkYFbQ58MW1R dvkYFbQ58MW1R]]

You can attach them to anything, so I have them on my keys (the fob) and remote(round sticker). Each have a button on so if you press one the others ring. It's also linked to an app on my phone, so they can make my phone ring even if it's on silent, or my phone can make them ring. I've also got it hooked up to Alexa so she can make ring them for me. So as long as you have one item you can find the rest!

Message:

Title: What kind of basic recipe can you not cook?
Message:
For poached eggs I use these - way better than dropping them into the water. Recommend ! 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Poacher-Cups-Pack-Perfect-Poached/dp/B06XF5S543/ref=mp_s_a_1_4?dchild=1&keywords=Silicone+Egg+Poacher&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611405620&sr=8-4]]

I was shit at rice too until a friend posted these instructions on Facebook: 
Put a dash of veg oil into a metal pan (youâ€™ll need one with a lid) and use your fingers to coat the inside of the pan with it. Not a lot, just a tiny bit. Put the heat on. After a few minutes add however much much rice you need and stir so it is all coated in the warm oil. After a minute or two add twice as much boiling water as there is rice (so half a cup rice = 1 cup water, etc). The water will get quite excited when it hits the pan! Stir through the rice ONCE then put the lid on and leave to simmer for 10 minutes. Take off the heat and set aside for 5 minutes. Take off lid and stir through ONCE - voila, fluffy rice. Donâ€™t overstir as that will make it mushy.

Title: Really struggling with decisions surrounding pain relief - anyone else?
Message:
I felt the same when I was pregnant with my first. 

I felt so much pressure from the midwives to have a birth plan and have intervention (sweeps, booking in for induction when I wasnâ€™t even overdue!)

I found this book really helpful

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Helping-Birth-Choices-Interventions-Childbirth/dp/1984249622?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

It gives you info and the pros and cons of each medication and things like sweeps and induction.

Like everyone else said, itâ€™s probably best not to have a definite plan but at least you are informed.

Title: Clothes for (slow) jogging in the witner
Message:
Gwenhwyfar, I feel your pain!  I'm cold-blooded, too.

Top: I wear one of these [[https://www.mountainwarehouse.com/merino-womens-round-neck-thermal-top-p13371.aspx/black/]] as a base layer (they're wool but I don't find them itchy), with a long-sleeved thinnish running top plus a shower-proof running jacket.  Psychologically, I think the wool makes me feel warmer.

Bottoms: I wear wool tights (everyday John Lewis wool tights, I keep old ones which have holes in for running) underneath normal running leggings.  If it's very cold, I add a pair of running socks as well (depends if your trainers are loose enough).  Alternatively, if I'm not wearing tights but think my feet will be cold, I wear smart wool socks, mine are something like these: [[https://www.smartwool.co.uk/uk/women-s-phd-run-cold-weather-mid-crew-3279.html]].  I find they're fine with mesh trainers.  They're not cheap but they're lovely and warm.

Hands: I think any kind of gloves are fine if they're comfy and keep you warm.  When I'm out, if my hands get hot, stuff the gloves either in a pocket or down my cleavage (ideally remembering to take them out before I go and buy a cup of tea at the end ...)

Head: I like a running head band which covers my ears but doesn't make my head too hot.

Lights: I have some trainer lights like these [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/SAKUUMI-Visibility-Reflective-Exercise-Activities/dp/B07WCNF1SY/ref=pd_lpo_200_t_1/257-4129835-3828506?psc=1&pf_rd_p=7b8e3b03-1439-4489-abd4-4a138cf4eca6&_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_wg=ZeKYh&pf_rd_r=GHH70MPG095KPCQ8R2S0&pd_rd_i=B07WCNCWRY&pd_rd_w=Ni7Fp&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&refRID=GHH70MPG095KPCQ8R2S0&pd_rd_r=04b7e891-620c-4830-8428-c9403d69137a]] which are very good for visibility.

I also find that it helps to get changed half an hour or so before I run and then put thick slippers on until I leave the house so that my feet are warm before I start.  

I really wish I had better circulation and didn't have to wear so many layers, but I guess it would be worse if I weren't exercising.

Title: To ask about how to unblock my ear
Message:
Both DH and I have had a problem with this this year.

Mine I stupidly caused myself with a cotton bud. I could tell as soon as I put the cotton bud in that it had pushed the wax in further; I could just fee it going in. I used Cerumol and after 2-3 weeks it cleared up and has been fine since.

DHs problems are more long standing. It first started last year and he eventually went to the GP. He also started using Earol and by the time he got to the GP it was nearly better. GP suggested getting them syringed. Because it seemed better he never got around to it. However, it has been a recurring problem this year. The oil helps a bit but it keeps coming back. After seeing these on another thread I have ordered a [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B07YYW5R4H/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 Wireless Otometer]] for him for Christmas. Some people speak highly of them.

Title: Please help me
Message:
Hi OP, firstly a big BIG hug for you. 

Spidermomma talks real sense - can you print her message out or photograph it so you can read it when you need it? 

You mentioned being grateful for lots of things - do make a list of those things too, and stick it up to remind yourself. 

You have the power to turn this around OP.  Can you also list some things you'd like to do or achieve, or that would be fun with the kids? Do one every week. 

Please contact Gingerbread - [[https://www.gingerbread.org.uk/information/young-single-parents/]]

And Home Start - [[https://www.home-start.org.uk/supporting-young-mothers]]

And do talk to your mum - are you bubbled with her or someone else? As a single parent you can bubble with another household. 

I have a book that might help, which I would love to send you if I could. If you'd like me to it's this - it's about rebuilding your life after a relationship break down. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Break-up-Crisis-Confidence-recover-break-up/dp/1838044507?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Just send me a DM if you'd like it.

We'll done for reaching out for help OP. XX

Title: Women who do it all...What is your routine?
Message:
I don't do it all, DH does a lot and I still only manage 1,2,5,8,9 from above and working on more time for 4 and 6.  No outsourcing and little family support, three children, ft job.

I am reading this and trying not to make myself ill by living up to standards that are not possible or going to work for me.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Rushing-Womans-Syndrome-Never-Ending-Do/dp/1781808163?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Ds (13) sobbing uncontrollably about lack of hobbies and talents - where have  gone wrong
Message: OP - there's a brilliant book called [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Drive-Ways-Motivate-Your-Achieve-ebook/dp/B06XCPR6BD?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Drive]] by an American headmistress. It really helps a parent find the balance between encouraging DC to stick at stuff and letting them lie fallow and get bored while they figure out what it is they want to do. The author's a great believer in not over-scheduling a child but insisting that if they do try something, they give it a proper go for a whole year. And she's good at making a distinction between desire and drive. Desire: I wish I was a rock star. Drive: I want to learn that bass line this week. Helping DC realise the difference was quite a breakthrough to them.

Title: Ds (13) sobbing uncontrollably about lack of hobbies and talents - where have  gone wrong
Message:
Some suggestions:

(1) Have a look at his book, he might appreciate it: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/You-Are-Awesome-Confidence-Bestseller/dp/1526361159/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=you+are+awesome&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609631189&sr=8-1]]

(2) What about something like Geocaching? [[https://www.geocaching.com/play]]

(3) Might he enjoy online museum tours?

(4) My husband at that age got really into baking cakes. Might he enjoy cooking? 

(5) Might he like photography? Or animation? Does he know how to code, he may be able to design his own computer games.

Having said all that, I don't think I had a hobby at his age...

Title: Ds (13) sobbing uncontrollably about lack of hobbies and talents - where have  gone wrong
Message:
I don't know if your DS is on social media but when I was a teacher the kids told me it massively affected their self esteem and how they felt about themselves. It is a total bragathon - was that kid telling him in class he had read LOTR in French or did he see it online? I think one possibility is online bragging is a thing now and that may be a factor. Disregard if not relevant!

He sounds like a normal 13 year old that is still figuring himself out. At that age I was writing stories and also hating playing the clarinet but persevering anyway [grin] now I'm a paid writer. Like a PP says, perhaps this could be a possibility?

If he does pick the guitar up my old tutor said this book was his favourite pick of last year to help with creativity: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/How-Write-Song-Jeff-Tweedy/dp/0571367208/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=how+to+write+one+song+jeff+tweedy&sprefix=how+to+write+one+&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609631061&sr=8-1]]

I hope your son feels better soon. 13 is a hard age and covid/school upheaval must be hard too.

Title: I LTB but please keep holding my hand - thread 2
Message:
**I explained that I don't think that he's an inherently bad person and does he genuinely want to hurt me - no - but he can't help himself.**

 A man who abuses, particularly with violence, is very unlikely to ever admit that he genuinely wants to hurt his victim. But when an abuser says you wind him up, won't do as you're told, do something wrong, show disrespect, wear the wrong clothes, say the wrong thing or whatever crime it is that you're supposed to have committed ... then the abuser is saying that they are ^justified^ in what they do. It's a subtle difference, but the outcome is the same.

They are very unlikely to change. In this book [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Why-Does-He-That-Controlling-ebook/dp/B000Q9J0RO/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&crid=3HFC2UPQP8UGQ&keywords=why+does+he+do+that&sprefix=why+does%2Caps%2C190&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607883832&sr=8-1 'Why Does He Do That? Inside the minds of angry and controlling men' written by Lundy Bancroft]] the man who wrote it says that after decades of trying to counsel abusers he realised it hardly ever worked.

**I explained that I still loved him and as DDs father, it would be irresponsible for me to encourage her to have a relationship with him until he has sought therapy, understands, is willing to change and move on. **

I'm sorry OP, but the man you love is a mirage. You love the man you thought he was, not who he actually is. You will go through a grieving process similar to if your STBX had died (and it's a good way to explain this dimension of what you're going through). You deserve so much better than the man he's turned out to be.

As for your DD maintaining her relationship with him, where there is violent abuse it's not advisable.

I think you are at the point where some professional support and advice would be very helpful. I think you should try to get back to the police and finish that statement. Many police forces have specialist DV officers who can be really helpful. It might be that they will remove him from the house and you can return. But you would need a non-mol order for that to work (hard to get over Xmas). Plus a lot of courage and support because he will try to worm/threaten his way back in and then of course, if you did allow him back, SS will be involved because you and DD would be in great danger.

WA will help you enormously if you can get through and access them.

Title: Is she really to far behind ! What reading programmes do you use.
Message:
Reading
[[https://www.soundfoundations.co.uk/product-category/dancing-bears/ dancing bears]] 10 minutes very day and I found it easier than some of the other programs recommneded here.

reading practise:

[[https://www.teachyourmonstertoread.com/about-the-game/what-does-each-game-cover?gclid=Cj0KCQiA3NX_BRDQARIsALA3fILW76KSSNtp4iBylx1khuCgwnaTEKN4N2nAHga04vO_JY1LWOemad8aAsx_EALw_wcB teach your monster how to read]]

[[https://www.readingchest.co.uk/ reading chest]] for pratcise books.

spelling
[[https://www.soundfoundations.co.uk/product-category/apples-pears/  Apple and pears]] - same peopel as dancing bears - really good but there is writing involved.


Also liked [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Signposts-Spelling-Joy-Pollock/dp/0435106864?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 sign post for spelling]] but it's an older program.




Handwriting
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Write-start-Programme-Perceptual-Handwriting/dp/1855032457/ref=asc_df_1855032457/?hvlocphy=9045651&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&psc=1&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvadid=311266996946&hvpone&hvlocint&th=1&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-466623723023&hvrand=18206889153379503656 write form the start]]

older children - though may have useful activites
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Speed-Up-Kinaesthetic-Programme-Handwriting/dp/1855033860/ref=pd_all_pref_n_1/262-8091436-2735643?psc=1&pf_rd_p=4d27882c-9fe7-40fd-a2ba-f8a742cae628&_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_wg=gECEZ&pf_rd_r=8N2PCZ4VJ448YBZ5MK1B&pd_rd_i=1855033860&pd_rd_w=cnBoo&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&refRID=8N2PCZ4VJ448YBZ5MK1B&pd_rd_r=79ea10e9-8a89-4b57-96ae-9a574d50a4b8 Speed up]]

handwriting slopes and activties than build hand muscule control also worth looking at.

[[https://www.nessy.com/uk/ Nessy]] - might help with writing  development but avoid handwriting.


If later you have any concerns about maths - really rate [[https://www.themathsfactor.com/ mathsfactor]]

Mine all caught up -and doing well in secondary school.

Primary board onhere was a great resource for us so many great teachers and other parents giving helpful advice.  Though best advice is little and often and don't try and sort everything at once it will take time.

Title: To give up breastfeeding
Message:

Sorry for massive link!

Title: Give me your star ideas for female hair loss - please!
Message:
i take these (when i remember): [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Phyto-Phytophanere-Food-Supplement-Nails/dp/B07MB2F5DV/ref=sr_1_8?dchild=1&crid=3C0KAE3G04C0X&keywords=phytophanere+capsules+hair&sprefix=phytophan%2Cstripbooks%2C159&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609866063&sr=8-8]]

you're supposed to take 2 months on, 1 month off so 4 months worth is actually 6 months supply. they've definitely helped a bit (think it's just genetic with me as my mum/aunts all have thinning hair despite having mops of hair when younger), to the extent that the hairdresser i was seeing when i first started taking them commented on it.

i have also given up dying in my hair and am embracing the white/grey/whatever look and I think that is helping as well. i'm now 20months since i last dyed my hair and while the front is still thinner than i'd like there has been an improvement.

Message:

Return a Gift

The Returns Center allows gift recipients to return items marked as a gift at the time of purchase. The type of refund or credit you receive depends on how the gift was purchased and how it's returned. Gift recipients won't be eligible for exchanges or instant refunds.

Note: Gift returns are confidential.

Title: Post Pill TTC - Party Hard with a Vengeance

Title: Anyone have any miracle burn remedies?! Warning: picture of said burn!

Message:

Title: ...to buy a ukulele
Message:
Thank you all for the encouragement, ideas, quotes and links. Lots to think about. DP will be completely [hmm], but he has his scotch, I will have my ukulele... I'll even let him use it, if he wants to. He won't.

This [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06W9GN7ZK/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?psc=1This&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]] is the one I bought, supposedly Â£50 RRP, but I didn't check, I just liked that one.I figure if I take to it (unlikely, but still) I can upgrade; if that happens, we have a friend whose son is a very good guitarist, so he might enjoy tinkering on it. 

*fuzzy*, your post has made me sad; I hope you can get what you want.

Banjolele always makes me think of Julie Walters in a Victoria Wood sketch... was it an Acorn Antiques episode? I'll have to look for it.

Title: What have you bought recently that has brought you joy?
Message:
So many tabs open to look at these gorgeous things! Love love the needlepoint  ðŸ˜ I also love the Cable & Cotton lights . I've been meaning to get some a while, but can never decide on what colours.

Our most recent purchase is our wood burner which we love very much. Especially now we have some decent wood bought from a local guy, who is also a builder whose work we've seen around but didn't realise was him, so a great contact for the future!

I bought a moon gazing hare ornament from fb marketplace which I just love [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Leonardo-Collection-Bronze-Ornament-Wildlife/dp/B06XC15NG9?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Pramsuits have no â€œfeetâ€ in them after 12months. Need warm â€œshoesâ€
Message: Fleece lined [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B003SEQ8ZQ/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_4PPTZGB7S70KV8ZRBRF2?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 playshoes]] are great for this.  They come quite far up the leg and they comfortably go over soft shoes when baby wears them.

Title: Moving from cot to toddler bed
Message:
In contrast to pp, we moved dd1 at about 19 months because she seemed ready (although never tried climbing out). 

We got a John Lewis bed with half-size removable rails on each side to keep her in, and got a toddler duvet/pillow set from argos. I also got a duvet strap like
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Cosy-Grips-Single-Duvet-Clips/dp/B000NC6GPS/ref=asc_df_B000NC6GPS/?hvlocphy=1006804&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvadid=309952929592&hvpone&hvlocint&hvpos&hvdev=m&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-562313445014&hvrand=18114362315414196782 this]] because after the first couple of days i realised she had no idea how to keep a duvet on. She loved it, all went well. She already had a gro clock, so new she had to stay and play quietly in her room until the sun came up on that which helped.

Title: 'They will catch up'
Message:
just a note OP - some kids learn much better with things to touch! Something like this might be helpful for your maths: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Learning-Resources-Mathlink-Cubes-Set/dp/B000URL296/ref=asc_df_B000URL296/?hvlocphy=1007266&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvadid=226587831116&hvpone&hvlocint&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-312502561092&hvrand=1102185532815067236]]

Or coins (lots of pennies and 10ps) or beads are good too.

Title: Dishwasher Tabs
Message:
You need dishwasher salt and you need rinse aid, most importantly you need the finish tablets linked.

I've tried all the other cheaply brands and they don't work, they leave a milky film on glasses. 

I can Chuck whatever without rinsing into the dishwasher including trays that have had 3 hour baked meats in and they come out brand new.

Finish Quantum Ultimate Dishwasher Lemon Scent, Pack of 85 Tablets [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 api]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 fabc]]c_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07MM5LRDL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_543CXW2F69KN61593H15 543CXW2F69KN61593H15]]


Oh and clean your filter regularly!

Title: Potty training advice please!
Message:
Sorry if this has been mentioned but have you thought about going straight to the toilet rather than a potty because sheâ€™s a bit older?

Something like this works really well so they can take themselves.

Title: Children's sleep during lockdown
Message:
[quote Haveyoubrushedyourteeth]Same here OP, no solutions, but huge sympathy. I know mine is shattered because she's far more weepy than usual during the day, but no matter what I do she can't switch off at night - sometimes it's gone 2am. We're cuddling, talking, using worry monsters, tiring her out,  doing mindfulness exercises, audio books lavender baths ....but nothing is working. I've just picked up my phone to see if I can find her a weighed blanket, its all I can think of now.[/quote]
Iâ€™ve ordered one from Amazon tonight for about Â£23. 

Brentfords Weighted Blanket Adults Teenagers Kids Therapy Sensory Anxiety Autism Insomnia Stress Relief-Silver Grey-125 x 150cm, 4kg(9lb) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0851K3ZVK/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_6MYKRTXPNW68FQJQNG4F?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Message:

Message: I have this (in black, I call it my tea penguin). Keeps it hot for hours. Holds just under a litre.  [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000NDKRYS/ref=twister_B08CDF4Z62?th=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: 9 week old puppy hates being left alone when I do the school run
Message:
Buy the happy puppy handbook. Pippa Mattinson who wrote it also has a super helpful website called the labrador site.  You have to be firm.  Labradors want to please, they are one of the easiest breeds to train. But they can also learn that you are a pushover!
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/0091957265/ref=tmm_pap_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1607631651&sr=8-6 https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/0091957265/ref=tmm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/0091957265/ref=tmm_pap_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1607631651&sr=8-6 pap]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/0091957265/ref=tmm_pap_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1607631651&sr=8-6 title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1607631651&sr=8-6]]

Title: Cookbook suggestions for an autistic 10 yr old (pref veggie)?
Message: I have this bread book that might appeal if he likes Bake Off? It's got other baked goods in, not just bread, and has loads of pictures for each recipe but not quite like the book in your imagination! Written for adults so may need a fair bit of support but it's a brilliant book that I've cooked loads from and it's all been great  [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Step-Step-Bread-Demonstrates-Technique/dp/0756692660?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: South Africa
Message:

Title: Invisalign
Message:
[quote Tinkletwat]Glad to hear * things are easing. I meant to add one of the best things I bought was a set of hooks to remove them, along the lines of these: 5 Pieces Aligner Removal Tool Invisible Tooth Removal 20 Pieces Teeth Interdental Brushes Toothpick Brush Cleaners for Invisible Braces Tooth Cleaning Remove Tool [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 api]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 fabc]]c_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07ZSFNZS5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_SUH-Fb7M3XQK7 SUH-Fb7M3XQK7]]

They're handy especially if you have weak or painted nails you don't want to damage. [/quote]
hopefully getting there although the top aligner still feels really thick on my top teeth and there's a weird sucking sensation (that doesn't really make sense but not sure how to describe it!) 

I'm going to order some of those hooks, thanks v much

Title: C Section and Post Partum belly bands
Message:
Hi lovely mums. I had an emergency c section 3 weeks ago. I still have a small round belly sticking out. I had bought the below post partum belly bands to use in case of a normal birth delivery. Has any you used similar bands with a CS? When did you start using them? Did you use them over a tshirt or on your bare skin?

Thank you in advance!!

Title: DD has developed a tic
Message:
My dd developed tics, I tried lots of things and they were getting worse and worse and worse. 

4 weeks ago I tried hemp oil capsules, she hasn't had a single tic since.

Hers were vocal, blinking, neck movements, shoulder movements and hitting herself.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/1000mg-Supplement-Softgel-Capsules-Strength/dp/B07P56C228/ref=mp_s_a_1_4?hvlocphy=1007327&hvnetw=g&keywords=hemp+oil&hvadid=259082681920&qid=1612387675&dchild=1&gclid=CjwKCAiAsOmABhAwEiwAEBR0ZiqcQnfTCk_jdnDTrDpJaAkq1wKr7Hz1RO4mu43Q-W2e3gKYTNgg7xoC4uAQAvD_BwE&hydadcr=7433_1810710&hvdev=m&hvqmt=e&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=kwd-295496369507&adgrpid=52749544545&hvrand=15977663832508029277&sr=8-4 these]] are the ones I got her. 

I didn't expect them to work, certainly not as effectively and quickly as they have but I 100% recommend them, or you can get drops if your dc can't take capsules.

Title: Christian Coffee House - Prayer/Chat thread. No rubbish church coffee allowed.
Message:
Hello  and  thanks for sharing your stories. A lot resonates with me as a relatively recent revert to Catholicism. I love stories of being drawn to God and of answered prayer. I think converts and reverts have more insecurity about Faith as they dont want to take it for granted and feel the loss of the years where it just didn't matter to them, and wanting to show your faith as best you can but uncertain you can do it right. If that makes any sense to you?

Prayers also for , if you are being drawn to faith that is worth exploring but please don't worry about Hell and damnation. Just see where your explorations take you and pray to God for guidance.

Revelation is an odd book and it sits apart from the rest of the NT. I dont know enough about it and plan to read [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1444749676/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_T1mbGbC6ST8AS?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Revelation Road]] by Nick Page at some point to find out more. For now I'm more interested in his book about how Jesus started his ministry. That's my next Nick Page book (Thanks *MHD* you were right I have read more of his books after starting with the history of Christianity, he's very readable). 

Could I ask for a prayer please for Ursula a reader in my church who died yesterday? She was old and her husband died a while ago. She was always in church and organised a lot. She wasn't ill so her death was sudden. I've worried about her all through the pandemic and now it seems she died of natural causes not Covid. Can we speed her on her way? I feel sure she's beginning a wonderful adventure of finding out what comes after.

Message:

Title: Best gloves for post-covid damaged hands
Message:
Dc2 has raynauds phenomenon and wears these [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07K66VHRF/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_ADYNWAPM7MK6B5SAZDQK?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
over fingerless gloves in the house or thin gloves and ski gloves when out. Also puts gloves on radiators before wearing and has an electric hand warmer to make sure hands are at a reasonable temperature before going out.
If all this doesn't work the GP can prescribe medication such as nifedipine.

Title: How to talk to teenagers so that they listen?
Message:
They are testing the boundaries and are finding them almost non-existent.

You are not alone, but it is such hard work to tackle this sort of behaviour, especially on your own. 

The book someone recommended is worth a read. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Get-Out-Life-bestselling-teenagers/dp/1781253315/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&quartzVehicle=45-608&crid=1U3ADXPJSUVIH&keywords=get+out+of+my+life+but+first&sprefix=Get+out+%2Caps%2C172&replacementKeywords=get+out+of+my+but+first&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1608050567&sr=8-1 this]] is a British book saying the same thing which we found invaluable. They explain why they behave like they do, what to do and also what not to do, which is just as important.

You need infinite resources of patience, but consistency and firmness will prevail in the end.

Title: 4yo behaviour
Message:
Oh, I do remember one thing that did help. Not with the running off, but some of the techniques described in this book really helped with DS.

The one about giving them what they want in pretend-world instead of just saying no, for example, worked wonders with DS.

eg "I want that cake!!" "Ooh, I love cake too. Imagine if we could eat a cake THIS big every day! What if our house was made of cake?" etc. 

Melt down averted. Magic!

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Calmer-Easier-Happier-Parenting-Revolutionary/dp/144472990X?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: How To Explain To  A 7 year old About His Dad Going To Prison
Message: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/My-Daddys-Jail-Anthony-Curcio/dp/0692470433?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: How To Explain To  A 7 year old About His Dad Going To Prison
Message:
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/My-Dads-Prison-Jackie-Walter/dp/1445161338?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Thereâ€™s books out there, youâ€™d have to judge what would work for your boy.
It sounds like your ex is having a hard time with the info. Not an easy thing for her to hear Iâ€™d guess. Youâ€™ve had time to process, but youâ€™ll need to give her time? Her fist reaction will be angry and upset. Sheâ€™s hopefully going to calm down when she hears you just want to help your son find the easiest path through. 
Best of luck with it all, the biggest thing you could do for your son is demonstrate for him people can rise up from a dark place and make changes. He could be so proud of you. Donâ€™t give up, better days will come.

Title: to ask how you manage severe endo pain and work
Message:
You have my sympathy OP. Iâ€™ve had two laparoscopies for endometriosis - I was lucky to have a sympathetic female gp who diagnosed me in my 20s. 

I would ask for a different gp and request codeine and naproxen to help manage the pain. Over the counter cocodol doesnâ€™t cut it for me, but it might work for you if youâ€™re not on it already. Tell them itâ€™s massively affecting your quality of life and your ability to work. I only take it on the days when itâ€™s really really unbearable.

Thereâ€™s a shortage of naproxen at the moment so the Feminax ultra you can usually buy over the counter is out of stock in large parts of the country.

Buy a plug in heat pad that you can wrap around you - I have one like this:  DIZA100 Heating Pad with Auto Shut Off, Fast Heating Technology, Machine Washable,Soft Flannel Safe Heating Pad for Back Muscle Neck Shoulder Pain Relief (12 x 24 inches) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07XP2RQHY/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_i_HF2.Fb9EG592F?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

I used to take the progesterone only pill on a 3-monthly cycle to control it but the one I was on was discontinued [angry]. I understand you not wanting it given your other health issues though. [flowers]

Title: Nursing bras advice
Message:
I asked a similar question on here a few days ago. First, measure yourself using boob or bust. You'll probably come out a lot larger than you thought but I do think it's right for a properly fitting bra!

I was recommended this from Amazon which arrived next day via prime and is VERY comfortable. It has loads of hooks on the back so seems like will last through pregnancy (I'm on the tightest one now) and super stretchy and comfy but supportive. 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00JWIAENE/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_y3l5FbR3R35AF?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: To ask you which the best epilator is? Buying one for daughter's Xmas present and never bought one before!
Message: I've got the silk epil 5-511 which comes with a starter head. You're meant to move on to the normal head after 4 weeks but I tried it and that was too painful for me! With the starter head I can do my armpits and bikini line so I'm happy not to change it. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Braun-Silk-epil-Cordless-Epilation-Beginners/dp/B01N5W6VZO/ref=mp_s_a_1_16?dchild=1&c=ts&s=drugstore&ts_id=74080031&keywords=Epilators+%26+Accessories&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1608669261&sr=1-16]]

Message: I started learning to draw with [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0738212415/ref=cmswrcpapifabckMI6FbKHBN6QC You Can Draw in 30 Days]] by Mark Kistler. It's absolutely brilliant. Title: How to be an organised mum? please can you share your organisation tips and Mum hacks?
Message:
I use something like this for meal planning for the week. I work full time and have two now secondary age children but have worked this system for years.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Group-Magnetic-Calendar-Shopping-Children/dp/B081XGK7XH/ref=sr_1_8?crid=HYJWDWTS694S&dchild=1&keywords=magnetic+whiteboard+for+fridge&qid=1609605899&sprefix=Magnetic+whiteboard%2Caps%2C385&sr=8-8 https://www.amazon.co.uk/Group-Magnetic-Calendar-Shopping-Children/dp/B081XGK7XH/ref=sr]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Group-Magnetic-Calendar-Shopping-Children/dp/B081XGK7XH/ref=sr_1_8?crid=HYJWDWTS694S&dchild=1&keywords=magnetic+whiteboard+for+fridge&qid=1609605899&sprefix=Magnetic+whiteboard%2Caps%2C385&sr=8-8 1]]1_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Group-Magnetic-Calendar-Shopping-Children/dp/B081XGK7XH/ref=sr_1_8?crid=HYJWDWTS694S&dchild=1&keywords=magnetic+whiteboard+for+fridge&qid=1609605899&sprefix=Magnetic+whiteboard%2Caps%2C385&sr=8-8 8?crid=HYJWDWTS694S&dchild=1&keywords=magnetic+whiteboard+for+fridge&qid=1609605899&sprefix=Magnetic+whiteboard%2Caps%2C385&sr=8-8]]

Meal planning done on a Friday before shopping on Saturday (previously on the shop but due to COVID now all online). Calendar appointments and birthdays etc recorded in family iCal to allow everyone to add their appointments, but also transferred to the weekly fridge board along with reminders for each day e.g. musical instrument, p.e. Kit etc. Children then have to check fridge each day to see what they need to pack and what their activities are for each day.
Essentially, I find I have to deal with stuff as it comes in. Anything put to one side to deal with later usually isn't!

Title: What nationality is this plug please?!
Message:
You need to show us the other end, and possibly measure it - it's a plug, like one of the ones on
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/MEROM-Universal-Chargering-Connector-1-35mm/dp/B08GLJ4PGJ/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
No need to pay that much though, but you do need to identify which one you need, then you either buy the USB cable, or a whole power bank depending on what's best for you.   Most people have lots of USB power plugs laying around.

Title: What nationality is this plug please?!
Message:
Now that looks like   5.5mm x 2.1mm which is a very common size, if you have a normal kids ruler measure the outside on the end and the inside between the black, it should be 5.5mm on the outside and 2.1mm on the inside - although it could be something close as there are other close sizes.   If it is that you can just get a USB one like:
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00SCBAE00/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
for a couple of quid and plug it in to any USB supply (almost all will be as powerful as the wall wart in your first picture) or you could buy a whole wart that has a similar connector.

Or just buy a US to UK plug adapter, that works too, but the cable alone is probably cheapest.

Title: Dec Earn Â£10/day. Santa's coming (hopefully with sacks of money!)
Message:
You can absolutely just do things 5 days of the week. 

For KDP this is an example of a no content notebook (not mine)
[[https://smile.[[amazon.co.uk/Mums-Notebook-Mary-Ochigbo/dp/B08NF32HHN/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/Mums-Notebook-Mary-Ochigbo/dp/B08NF32HHN/]]]] They've made the cover in Canva or similar and the inside they've either bought very cheaply from somewhere like Creative Fabrica or made themselves. 

This is a low content one:
[[https://smile.[[amazon.co.uk/Christmas-Colouring-Book-Kids-Collection/dp/B08NMDMXQN/?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/Christmas-Colouring-Book-Kids-Collection/dp/B08NMDMXQN/]]]]

At the moment I am concentrating on colouring books (I get the pages from Creative Fabrica and edit them to make them my own) and sudoku puzzles (I've bought a fancy spreadsheet that makes them from Bowes Publishing for my Christmas present [blush]) 

Just be warned there are a lot of people out there selling stuff to help you make money. Do a lot of research first. There are also facebook groups too where you can get help and pick up ideas. 

This is a British Youtuber that will explain things a lot better than me. (And try and sell you his courses [grin] ) [[https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0mQ5AgWwp4qKDGEoZrDcjA]] His facebook group is good to join.

This is a fab place to download free stuff from: [[https://gumroad.com/bowespublishing]] His facebook group is also excellent.

Title: Baby eczema
Message:
My DS has bad excema from when he was a baby. We used hydrocortisone when he had flare ups and Aveeno when he didn't. He is 15 now and has more or less grown out of it. We used to have to avoid soap and use special cleansers and products for sensitive skin. Holiday were times when we had bad flare ups as the mixture of sun cream sweat etc used to be an issue. We had to use special sun cream with Vaseline underneath it. I would recommend Aveeno and I think they do baby products now. We used to get the lotion on prescription but not that's possible now as the rules have changed.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Aveeno-Baby-Daily-Moisturising-Lotion/dp/B07R594C45/ref=mp_s_a_1_1_sspa?dchild=1&keywords=aveeno+baby&qid=1607464703&s=baby&sr=1-1-spons&psc=1&spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUExWUJUVDhTTTkyWFBKJmVuY3J5cHRlZElkPUEwMTgzMTg4WDAxMzgxSjFJMks4JmVuY3J5cHRlZEFkSWQ9QTA0OTEwNDYxSEtaV1VURkxEVzI3JndpZGdldE5hbWU9c3BfcGhvbmVfc2VhcmNoX2F0ZiZhY3Rpb249Y2xpY2tSZWRpcmVjdCZkb05vdExvZ0NsaWNrPXRydWU Title: Plant ID please (with a difference!)
Message:
*The third one looks like a small-leaved lime (Tilia cordata) to me.* No, I don't think so, because the leaf of Tilia cordata tapers in the upper half whereas this is very full in width almost to the top. In that respect it's more like Corylus avellana (hazel) but the dentition is wrong.

The two bottom veins in Tilia cordata are at 45 degrees to the centre rib, not at nearly 90 degrees like this one

 Have you come across [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Vegetative-Key-British-Flora/dp/0956014402?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 "The Leaf Key" by Poland and Clement]]? They've just published a new one, on [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Planted-Deciduous-Climbers-Xylophytes-British/dp/0956014437/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&s=books&keywords=poland+winter+twigs&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1608545828&sr=1-1 Winter twigs]] covering both native and planted species, which I thought you might be interested in. I've got it on my Christmas list.

Title: Can we share ideas to make the best of the next couple of months?
Message:
Iâ€™m a classical music lover but tend to stay in my comfort zone. 
This [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/YEAR-WONDER-Classical-Music-Every/dp/1472252306/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&crid=25MCF4QX81TR3&keywords=a+year+of+wonder+by+clemency+burton+hill&sprefix=A+year+of+w%2Caps%2C180&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609975239&sr=8-1 book]] was recommended on MN with a piece of Classical or 20th Century music plus some interesting background facts every day. I got the Kindle version and can just copy and paste the title into YouTube.
Itâ€™s usually less than half an hour, so a coffee break activity just for myself.

I also bought a paint-by-numbers canvas, but it came from China and Lockdown 1 was over by the time it arrived. Now, I wonder where I put it!

Title: Can we share ideas to make the best of the next couple of months?
Message:
Last one!
I highly recommend this audio book by Sophie Sabbage. She's a very experienced trainer and has also written a highly regarded book about cancer  having suffered from a brain tumour herself. This audio book is actually more like listening to a workshop as you hear Sophie support people with their emotion arising from the challenges coronavirus has thrown them. It's very powerful and hopefully helpful to people. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/B08G1RF86T/ref=cm_cr_arp_mb_bdcrb_top?tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

Title: I don't want my kids to be vegetarian
Message:
Might I recommend this book? Full of recipes which can be done with or without meat, some of which involve adding meat at the last moment, so you can all eat the same thing

[[https://smile.[[amazon.co.uk/dp/0711239045/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_itaZFbAQY233B?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/dp/0711239045/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_itaZFbAQY233B]]]] 

You may also be pleasantly surprised by the fake meat that's now on the market - five years ago it was awful, but now it's really quite good. Vivera is a reliable brand to start you off.

Title: I don't want my kids to be vegetarian
Message:
These books by Nicola Graimes are aimed at mixed families. The  recipes are designed be made meat free/meaty with a couple of small adjustments late in the prep :

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Part-Time-Vegetarian-Flexible-Recipes-Meat-Free/dp/1848992653?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Part-Time-Vegetarians-Year-Flexible-Recipes/dp/1848993811?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

If you all do meat free once or twice a week that would give you another two nights with single dish cooking.

At 15 and 13 they are also old enough to be cooking, maybe at weekends when there is more time.

If you say "no" you will simply create resentment.  If you agree to try it out you may find many new meals you enjoy as well to broaden the everyday recipe list for the house.

Title: So stressed about cooking for baby
Message:
Hi OP as pp have rightly pointed out, I missed the bit in your first post that said you mostly have ready meals. In that case, I highly rate this awesome cooking book for babies. It's has brilliant, easy-to-follow recipes and towards the end there are recipes that can be cooked for the whole family. I've recommend it to a few people irl and they have been been delighted with it.

Title: So stressed about cooking for baby
Message:
Iâ€™m just about to buy more of these pots for freezing NUK Food Cube Tray with Lid for Freezing Baby Food | 6 Months+ | Dishwasher Safe | BPA Free [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B004EWG9D2/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_h.xaGbXJ7J36X?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Last night DD 18mo had one of frozen mashed potato (I made loads extra a few weeks ago, added more milk and no salt to hers before freezing portions) plus one of a meat ragu,- 2 onions, carrots, celery sticks, garlic, pack mince fried up then 2 tins of tomatoes added. Made enough for about 16 meals.
To make her meal I literally popped one of each ice cube into her bowl, microwaved it for a minute then left to cool. If we have rice or chips Iâ€™ll give it to her with that but the frozen mash is great.
I also have one full of Jamie Oliver 7-veg tomato sauce which I serve with pasta (or any carbs - she loves dipping buttered toast into it).
If you always have 2 or 3 things in the freezer, you can generally add one to whatever you are having or put one on pasta.
Also If weâ€™ve had a rubbish food day (Mummyâ€™s pizza for lunch...) I add frozen peas / sweet corn to whatever is for dinner. Fruit for snacks. If sheâ€™s picky I grate cheese on anything and sheâ€™ll eat it.
Keep stocked up on fish fingers / veggie fingers too, and potato waffles, some brands have a lot less salt but I canâ€™t remember which.

Title: Is this THE pandemic?
Message:
[quote Marvelina]I agree with this, I just think that this more rational kind of approach should be applied more broadly to how these things are discussed and supported with the right evidence. I'm not referring to posts like that. I'm referring to posts that blithely predict apocalyptic doom within a few years without that kind of approach/support and I find these very cold and irresponsible. [/quote]
I think some of the green doom morgering is counter productive - gives  many an excuse of inertia as it increasing gets seen as inevitable.  There's potential money to be made from green tech  and I think some people let the persuit of prefection get in way of  improvements.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Factfulness-Reasons-Wrong-Things-Better/dp/1473637465?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Factfulness: Ten Reasons We're Wrong About The World - And Why Things Are Better Than You Think]] is a book showing how things have improved and many people aren't aware.

There's a lot of foucs on having children but the world population will stablise and around the world fertility levels have rapidly fallen quicker than expected [[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-53409521 Fertility rate: 'Jaw-dropping' global crash in children being born]]

People being aware of increased risks of viruses crossing species is good - more attention more work and importantly more funding.

Countries that were hit badly with SARS have on the whole done well with covid - it sucks we seem to have to learn lessosn the hard way but we could have had an even worse experince to learn from.

We've come up with mulitple vaccines in record time found several medical treatments that reduce risk of death - several of those came from UK.

If OP is in UK - it's a rich country with a  saftey net currently (though there are holes)  politically stable and one of the more gelogical areas in the world - it's one of the better places to be when these possible issues do hit.

Title: Terrible 3's????
Message:
[quote JiltedJohnsJulie]If her speech is delayed, I'd concentrate on this first, it will help her behaviour and help her settle into Nursery. Is she seeing a SLT and gave you had her hearing checked?

As for a book, I'd try the [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Discipline-Solution-Encourage-Behaviour-Tantrums/dp/0077117298 No Cry Discipline Solution]] [smile][/quote]
Thanks for your reply. Yes she's been referred to SALT after an assessment. Mild understanding & moderate speech issues. Her hearing has been checked and there's no issue there.  She hasn't had any therapy yet as were waiting for an appointment to come through after the initial assessment. Lockdown has understandably slowed everything down. 

When I met with her nursery school teacher before Christmas she said quite a few parents had commented on speech delay and they think it'll be common with lockdown. Hopefully as more things open up that will help. The school have sent some homeschool activities so it's great to have new ideas and she's really enjoying doing these and showing them to her dad when he gets home from work & talking about them.

I'll definitely check out the book. I used the oh crap potty training book a couple of months ago and it worked well. It helped with understanding the how her brain was interpreting everything.

Hopefully her behaviour is just another phase but I want to nip it in the bud ASAP

Title: Terrible 3's????
Message:
If her speech is delayed, I'd concentrate on this first, it will help her behaviour and help her settle into Nursery. Is she seeing a SLT and gave you had her hearing checked?

As for a book, I'd try the [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Discipline-Solution-Encourage-Behaviour-Tantrums/dp/0077117298 No Cry Discipline Solution]] [smile]

Title: Struggling tonight
Message:
Just read your post again, , and Iâ€™m so struck by your resilience. To get through all of that and be surviving and working is incredible.

A pp has mentioned therapy and if you can afford it, I definitely try to find a good therapist to deal with the fall-out of all youâ€™ve experienced. You should be able to get help on the NHS, but it may not be easy.

Meanwhile, Iâ€™d start really small. Sometimes these suggestions sound trite, but ðŸ¤·ðŸ»â€â™€ï¸ Waking up and opening your laptop sounds so miserable. What about leaving your laptop for ten minutes and going to make a hot drink and try to start the day just slightly differently? Some little new routine. Take your coffee to the window or similar. Thatâ€™s just a tiny first step that might feel more possible than take a shower/go for a walk etc which I know can feel impossible. 

Thereâ€™s some really helpful books you could look at to try to shift your perspective, which is totally understandably negative at the moment. One of the Russ Harris books,  The Reality Slap and/or The Happiness Trap. 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Reality-Slap-Russ-Harris/dp/1780332025?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

There loads of resources on sleep, but you might be sick of â€˜helpful adviceâ€™ on that. An easy thing to try could be a weighted blanket. Eg [[https://www.onlinehomeshop.com/blankets-throws/weighted-blankets]]

I hope you can start to change things a little - Christ, you deserve better. 

[flowers]

Title: Feeling a bit lost and hopeless with baby - help
Message: First of all don't think it is caused by anything you've done or haven't done, it's like lottery. We have this swing (https://www.amazon.com/Ingenuity-Inlighten-Cradling-Swing-Plug/dp/B07NPLRQRG ) if the link doesn't show it' ingenuity unicorn or something like that, it can move in various directions and helps a lot to calm them down then you should move him to the crib. Though babies also have their preferences, my first one loved being carried in the sling and the second one doesn't so much, so perhaps yours won't like the swing but it may be worth a try..

Title: Feeling a bit lost and hopeless with baby - help
Message:
*This is where itâ€™s just sad, as heâ€™s not in a proper eating or sleeping routine at all and if he was I think weâ€™d both be happier. But I donâ€™t see a way of making it happen*.

It will come though.  Neither of mine were in a rountine at 5 weeks, they just sort of fell into one a bit later without it being forced.

Like I said at the beginning, I really would throw the Baby Whisperer Book away.  It doesn't seem to be making you happy and babies are programmed to feed to sleep so you're actually trying to fight biological norms if you're trying to feed them keep him awake.  I've only known one close person who followed the Baby Whisperer and baby didn't sleep through till 7.  That's not weeks or months and the mother seemed very unhappy and frustrated that they weren't following the routine as well.

If you don't fancy the book I linked to earlier, try [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Babycalming-Simple-Solutions-Happy-Baby/dp/0007159021 Baby Calming by Caroline Deacon]]

I read it before having DC2 and really wish I'd read it before having DC1.

Have you managed to get any sleep over night?

Title: Feeling a bit lost and hopeless with baby - help
Message: You might find [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/No-Cry-Sleep-Solution-Newborns-Amazing/dp/1259641171 this book]] more helpful if he's really not sleeping.  Unlike the Baby Whisperer, this one is evidence based and there's no strict routine to follow [smile]

Title: Thoughts on the â€˜IPad generationâ€™
Message:
It's addictive. Google "screen time addictive" and you'll see all the articles and studies in it.

https://www.fatherly.com/health-science/screen-time-hurts-kids-dopamine-addiction/

As PP say, they are designed to trigger addictive behaviours. The way we pull down to refresh - that's the same motion gamblers do at slots in casinos. The way the timeline refreshes and you don't know if it will be interesting (win) or boring (lose) - that's by design. It's addictive.

Read https://www.amazon.co.uk/Arguments-Deleting-Social-Media-Accounts/dp/1847925391

The only question is are you OK with your children being addicted to screens and the content on them. Many people are, and that's their decision.

Title: Recommendations for a dishwasher
Message:
We've just bought a new one a [[https://www.johnlewis.com/bosch-sms46mi01g-freestanding-dishwasher/p4131599  Bosch from John Lewis]] it has a stainless steel front- we wanted integrated to replace the old one BUT we were governed by stock.  There was limited choice everywhere not just JL in December 

We now have a cutlery tray - downside of that is the top rack (or now the middle rack due to cutlery)  is lower down, so you have to dip down a bit more when loading/unloading.   Also it does not fit tall glasses,  and in the bottom rack the spikes are not long enough to support say a pint glass so I've had to buy [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B07KQDX32L/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o07_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8  these spike things from Amazon]] to use if we have tall glasses/water bottles etc

Though saying all of that, it is very quiet has a 45 min quick wash (though my previous one had a 30 min which I would prefer)  and overall does it's job well.

Title: Neighbours' noise making my life a misery
Message:
A White noise machine saved my sanity from neighbours, by no means would drown out all noise but prob (hopefully) most of the talking/laughing and you need to place it near the source of noise. I think this is a more modern version of the one I bought about 6 yrs ago, mnie is still going strong.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Marpac-Dohm-Classic-White-Machine/dp/B0?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]  The best of luck, excessive neighbour noise is beyond awful.

Title: Looking for quick and honest responses on robot vacuum cleaners
Message:
I have this one, absolutely love it. 
It goes off every night via a timer on the app. Constantly amazed at the fluff and dirt it picks up every night( I have teen boys and a Labrador!)
When I can be arsed I take it up to one of the other floors and let it loose during the day when no ones home. 
One of my best purchases ever.

Title: Looking for quick and honest responses on robot vacuum cleaners
Message:
After following a thread on here I impulse bought this one (Black Friday deal). [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B07XXXKBL9/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

It is brilliant. Small household - single parent, teenage DC and a short-haired cat. My teenager loves gadgets so took responsibility for all the set up - machine and apps.  I reckon the 1st weekend it did our landing (carpet) and bathrooms (vinyl) 10 times. It picks up so much pet hair, dust, bits. It is easy to use and clean. I really love using it in the kitchen (ceramic tiles) - it has a quick 30 min programme. 

For a laugh I took it over to my mum's house (support bubble). She has been unwell and struggles to hoover properly. So we set EUFY running upstairs and and I hoovered downstairs. It did brilliantly and she (in her 80s) is so tempted to get one. I do worry about her tripping on it. 

The only downside is that my teenager's plans to make a fortune on youtube from cat/robovac videos are not going well [grin] [grin]. Cat hates it!!

Title: Formula, but sometimes breast?
Message:
This is the one Medela makes:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1 https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1 s]]s_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1 a]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1 1]]1_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Medela-009-0005-Supplementary-Nutrition-System/dp/B00JZF8LHK/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1 1?dchild=1&keywords=medela+supplemental+nursing+system&qid=1612885172&sprefix=medela+su&sr=8-1]]

Here are some tips:

https://milkandmotherhood.com/2019/06/top-tips-for-using-an-sns.html

http://watanabe.fastmail.jp/sns.html

https://www.adelejarrettkerr.com/practical-tips-for-using-a-supplemental-nursing-system-sns/

You can try Googling 'supply line breastfeeding' 'supplemental nursing system' or 'at breast supplementation'.


There's also a Facebook group called supply line feeders of Australia, it is full of experts and not just for Australia, anyone can join. There's also a Facebook group called IGT and low milk supply support group, again a huge wealth of information there and the members are always happy to answer questions.

Title: Garden covered in cat sh*t! Repellent ideas that work, please!!
Message:
I bought this:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/aw/d/B004SGC75S?psc=1&ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_title&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

And put it in the top corner of the garden, pointing back towards the house, so that it covers the whole garden. I also sprinkled around a load of rosemary oil (cats hate the smell) and so far its working although they've started shitting in the garden next door instead. I've recommended the repeller to her.

Title: How do you paint your nails so they don't chip within 10 minutes?
Message:
I bought this kit from Amazon. It's one of the mylee kits and comes with everything you need including 4 colours. The only extra thing I use is a nail file to buff the nail when removing as it helps to break through the top coat (buff with file then wrap in remover with tin foil wrapped over). 

A good tip is to make sure you paint some top coat over your tips and also apply a nail oil daily. 

Mylee Complete Professional Gel Nail Polish LED Lamp Kit, 4x MYGEL Colours, Top & Base Coat, Mylee PRO Salon Series Convex CuringÂ® LED Lamp, Prep & Wipe, Gel Remover and more (Kit with Black Lamp) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 api]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 fabc]]c_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B075LJFX98/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1 RK3PDGGVCTGBDGN0BZXT?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1]]

Title: Cleaning Down Jackets
Message:
I use a wool wash with delicate detergent, then dry in a tumble dryer with natural wool balls like these: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Smart-Sheep-Premium-All-Natural-Softener/dp/B00GA9P5P0?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] 
The wool balls I linked to not only act like tennis balls and increase fluffiness, they also increase tumble dryer/energy efficiency.

Title: Suddenly awful skin
Running induced plantar faciitis-help!
Message:
Get a stretch board. I had terrible plantar that lasted months and 2 weeks stretching on the board and I was all better. It was magic. Someone on here recommended it. Mine flared up this week as I have been walking loads and can't swim. Used the board twice and it's stopped. I think my plantar is linked to super tight calves. The board just stretches your foor further than you can manage yourself.

Title: Fussy eater at 22 months
Message:
All the food he eats have sweetness in common *bread, plain pasta, various fruit, yogurt,crackers, soft cheese and breadsticks* 

We humans are animals of habits, we like what we know and repetition will consolidate feelings. 

I am not sure having the "safe" (and safe from what ?) food is helping. 

What I suggest you try is this: 
For a week - and I know he has a sister so you need to talk to her and tell her she is part of a secret plan - hide all the sweet biscuits, crisps, chocolate, and even the crackers and breadstick, they are as processed as they get.
During that week, change the meal dynamics, don't make them about him. Don't try to offer new stuff with that body/face language which is worried from the start he won't like it.  Make family meals about family. Change the settings, so if you usually eat in the kitchen , clear the dinning table and set the table for all of you. Move a chair to make room for his high chair or put a booster on a normal chair. All of you sit together, without making a fuss about him eating or not, Maybe during that week, don't make "one pot " dishes such as stew or pies , but have a chicken breast, a schnitzel, a battered fish (all possibly homemade to wean him for the processed food taste and additives if he has any) , and next to it, a couple of potatoes, and some veggies, but single. Also consider taste. Make your vegetables delicious using extra virgin olive oil, coarse salt, fresh herbs. Consider slicing a pumpkin and roasting it with garlic, fresh rosemary, salt and oil. 

It is not a punishment, it is adding stuff and new taste. Even the yoghurt, if he usually has a sweet tasting one, have good quality real plain yoghurt, to which you can add a bit of jam, with some  frozen berries which you let melt and simmer in a small pot on the stove. 
For breakfast, move away from sweet cereals (cheerios) and other processed food. You can make pancakes one morning (250 flour, 3 eggs, 1 tbls oil, pinch of salt, 500 ml milk)  or even a homemade cake. The problem is the processed food, even seemingly innocent food such as crackers and breadstick. 
You need to increase the variety, even if he won't touch it. Let the home family have different food every day, a wider variety of vegetables on the table, go for new food, such as homemade meatballs in tomato sauce. 
Have the meal together and try to ignore him, and focus on a family chat, talking about plans, don't ask " do you want to try" or " see if you like it" or " you want something else" . Just leave the dish in the middle of the table and put a spoonful in your plate, your daughter's , then your son, before moving to serving your husband. Sit down, say enjoy, and start eating and talking about a radio talk, your sister's cat or whatever, but the food or him eating/liking it. Talk about going to the park later or making some craft.  Have your daughter say at some point " this is nice, mom" . Show him everyone is eating it, have some, enjoying it. 
While you cook and prepare food, have him with you, standing on a chair put safely against the kitchen top (with back of chai\r against furniture) and while you cook, nibble here and there, take a bite of ham, dress your tomato salad and then talk "hum.... what does it need, a bit more salt /parsley, basil....," and have him add a pitch, mix, taste again and say "perfect "

When it comes to fussy eating  you need to take action on two fronts, the meal times dynamic and increasing the variety at the table. This mean that for a week, you don't cave in and jump to offer alternatives. 

Do some reading . I strongly recommend this book

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/First-Bite-How-Learn-Eat/dp/0007549725/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1612903548&sr=8-1]] 

and spend some time on pubmed reading medical papers on fussy eating.
[[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6398579/]]
