Title: Low Carb Lockdown Bootcamp - Jan 21 - Week 1 chat thread
Message:
*Bestbees* you can use a squirt of bottled lemon juice from the fridge instead of fresh lemon.

*Brassica* give yourself time. Exercise could well be masking your weight loss, especially if you have any delayed onset muscle soreness which is associated with water retention. KOKO and the whoosh fairy will head your way soon enough.

*Ouchmyfeet* I've been eating this way for seven years and I still add electrolytes to my water. [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00SP31TCW?ref=ppxpopmobapshare I buy these cheap ones from Amazon]] because artificial sweeteners don't agree with them. I had to have blood tests recently and my sodium levels were actually on the low side of normal so even though I feel like I'm adding a lot of salt to my food I must need it. I think a lot depends on the other foods you eat. I eat a very clean diet so I need the added salt. If you're eating more processed foods or cured meats then you might not need to keep adding electrolytes. Also if you're drinking excessive amounts of water and other fluids then you will be flushing electrolytes from your system that you will then need to replace. [[https://www.gundersenhealth.org/health-wellness/eat/are-you-over-hydrated/ Here's an article about over-hydration.]].* It also depends on how quickly you drink fluids. If you down a pint of water in one go then most of it will end up as urine - taking electrolytes with it. You need to drink continuously through the day. Alternatively if you're drinking water with added electrolytes like the ones I linked to, then more of it is absorbed so you can drink it much more quickly - useful if you only have limited opportunities to drink through the day.

Title: Low Carb Lockdown Bootcamp - Jan 21 - Week 1 chat thread
Message: *Wanderlove* [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0091924286/ref=cmswrcpapifabcSBcdGbSBCDR9A The Diet Delusion]] by Gary Taubes is a good one. He also has a new book out called The Case For Keto.

Title: Low Carb Lockdown Bootcamp - Jan 21 - Week 1 chat thread
Message:
*Nowlook* monounsaturated fats such as olive oil, avocado oil and nut oils are much healthier for you than polyunsaturated vegetable oils (sunflower, corn oil, etc.) It's because vegetable oils are pro-inflammatory due to their high omega-6 content. However from a weight loss point of view it won't make much difference apart from inflammation potentially contributing to water retention. Saturated fats such as butter, lard, dripping and goose fat are all fine to cook with. Although in fact, every one of the fats and oils I've mentioned are made up of different combinations of monounsaturated, polyunsaturated and saturated fats. For example lard contains more monounsaturated fat (widely regarded as healthy) than saturated fat (widely regarded as unhealthy.) The whole demonisation of saturated fat is completely made up and has been thoroughly debunked by journalist Nina Teicholz in her book [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/192522810X/ref=cmswrcpapifabcBXccGbMA02ZXV The Big Fat Surprise]] which is a brilliant read. Anyway, in short --I know, too late-- it's the ^proportion^ of omega-3 and omega-6 in your diet that's important. We want to tip that towards a healthy ratio by emphasising animal fats, monounsaturated fats (oil, avocado, nut) and fish oils, while minimising vegetable oils. So at home I don't use vegetable oils but I don't worry too much about what my food is cooked in for takeaway/restaurant meals because I know most of my fat intake is from healthy fats.

At the end of the day, I regard the fact that human body fat is 30% saturated as proof that saturated fat cannot be unhealthy. If it was unhealthy then why would we store so much of our body fat as saturated fat? There's actually a school of thought that implicates polyunsaturated fats as a major driver of the obesity epidemic, and not simply a consequence of carbohydrate consumption. After all, many primitive cultures ate high carbohydrate diets without suffering from obesity and diabetes, or even tooth decay.

Title: Low Carb Lockdown Bootcamp - Jan 21 - Week 1 chat thread
Message:
that soup/cauliflower looks amazing!

 

^B: coconut milk, quark and berry smoothie^

Why the berries?  Not allowed in the first two weeks of Bootcamp!  I'm also not sure why you're using Quark, as this is a low fat product - remember this is a high fat way of eating.

(And I hope that you swerved the white wine last night!)

 I'd be seriously pissed off that my colleague didn't tell me that ^before^ you'd eaten!  Don't worry about it though - just KOKO and all will be fine



^BIWI I heard you on the Mosely zoom chat - you're such a cuddly speaker!^

Not quite sure what that means, but thank you!  (I think?!) [grin]. Agree though, MM did go on a bit.  But I suppose zoom calls are unscripted and he didn't know what he was going to be asked - that's quite unusual, because when we've had webchats before, people post their questions in advance.  And I suppose if he'd had to type his answers, rather than speak, they would have been shorter.



Sorry.  It wasn't meant to be hate for vegans [grin]. Just the insistence/proselytising about veganism being the healthiest way to eat - which is patently can't be if you're eating so much processed food (even before you consider the potential lack of important nutrients) - and that it's healthier for the planet, when some practices clearly aren't!  

I think you're quite right when you say you haven't been eating enough fat - being hungry is a tell-tale sign!

 

I'm with you - I really, really, really love cheese.  And butter.  And yoghurt. 
 And eggs!  I love vegetables and pulses/legumes, and could - at a push - eat a mainly vegetarian diet.  But I just can't see how a totally vegan diet would be enjoyable.  For me.



^Hoping that as a veggie, almost vegan, this WOE is going to work for me. Having a few doubts now but I haven't had any problems so far so going to stick with it and hope all of my efforts pay off.^

It will work for you!  Possibly a bit slower, because if your diet is mainly vegetables then your carb count is inevitably going to be higher than if you were eating meat or fish.  Rose Elliott has created a [[low carb vegetarian diet, which you might want to explore - she's also written a [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Vegetarian-Low-Carb-Diet-Cookbook-vegetarians/dp/0749926988/ref=sr_1_4?dchild=1&keywords=rose+elliot+low+carb+vegetarian+recipes&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611305775&sr=8-4  recipe book to go with it, which has some lovely recipes  ]].  Have you checked out the vegetarian recipe in the Low Carb Bootcamp topic?  There are lots of great ideas in there.

(Oh, and thanks for delurking! [flowers] [smile])



^When should the sugar cravings start to subside, do you all think?^

Any time now, I should think!  You should find that by the time we finish the first two weeks of Bootcamp that you're having fewer and fewer cravings, although that does depend on how much of a sugar fiend you were beforehand.  Once you're used to low carbing, and haven't been eating fruit/desserts/sweets/biscuits/chocolate on a regular basis, that your tastes change.  I remember when Cadbury brought Wispa back again, and I rushed out to buy one as I used to love them - but it was like eating a mouthful of sweet, bubbly wax!  I was shocked.  These days, if I eat chocolate I much prefer dark chocolate --although I seemed to manage to put away a fair few Cadbury's Roses at Christmas!--

Title: Does anyone do their own gel polish nails??
Message:
I bought a lamp & polishes in March and itâ€™s been brilliant. 
 I prep after light buffing using this  Mylee Prep + Wipe Gel Nail Polish Residue Cleaner Remover 250ml, Preparation & After Care, UV LED Manicure Gel Polish Base Wipe, Multi-Purpose for Sanitising Nail Plate & Removing Tacky Layer [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00OZP8TIQ/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_Uoq0FbC8N8NAV?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] and you use it to wipe nails when finished too, it makes them glossy and removes the tacky surface. 

I bought this lamp 
54W UV Nail Lamp, DIOZO LED Nail Dryer Quick-drying LED UV Nail Dryer with 36 Dual Light Source LEDs, 4 Timer Setting [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07K25Q3HC/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_Zmq0FbVT84M1D?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

You need to buy lint free squares too to wipes nails with the prep liquid. 

I found Bluesky polishes and base/top last longest. I started off with CND polishes but it doesnâ€™t last as long! Polish usually starts to peel off after 2 weeks so I usually gently peel it all off. Hasnâ€™t  damaged my nails luckily. 

I do toes as well now. Iâ€™ll probably never go back to the salon!

Title: High chair to boaster seat
Message:
We went from the Ikea highchair to a BabyDan high chair but measure your table to make sure it fits under.

It is completely adjustable and we only moved DCs onto an actual dining chair when we had dropped the BabyDan seat down to the same level. 

I liked the fact that it sort of grew with the child. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/BabyDan-2638-02-Danchair-Natural/dp/B00INS0H4U?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: AIBU to think Sil is a CF?
Message:
I don't think she phrased it well and I think expecting you/DH to travel 60 miles (I'm assuming on public transport) while you're in tier 3 is a pretty big ask. Are they experienced landlords? because it's not unusual to get professional cleaners in at the end of a tenancy. 
 
As an aside: *I'm quite stressed/ busy with dc and my OCD (it has got worse during the lockdowns, but I'm reading some ocd books and slowly trying to reduce the amount of ocd rituals. I might ask to be put on waiting list for cbt but with lots of people suffering with their mental health I don't want to take the place of someone who may need it more.)* Don't wait for a MH crisis before seeking help, and don't worry about other people needing help more. Go get on that waiting list (which is probably pretty long anyway) put yourself FIRST because your health is important. [flowers] 
 If you're looking for CBT books, I found [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Cognitive-Behavioural-Therapy-Dummies-Branch/dp/0470665416?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 CBT for Dummies]] a really 'user friendly' book.

Title: Looking for some warm touch screen gloves
Message:
Just to update - I'd been trying to avoid Amazon but I've bought these knitted gloves with grip and I'm pleased with them:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07WDXY9M5/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_i_3YfaGb0MZNPYT?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

They're very grippy and work well on touchscreen. They're not quite as warm as lined, thinsulate ski-type gloves would be but they do the job very well. Incidentally I wore my ski gloves (I think they're Reusch) on a snowy walk last week and was amazed at how warm my hands were - I'd forgotten what they were like! Hopeless for taking photos though ðŸ˜

Title: Tax on goods from EU surely not correct?
Message:
[quote MrsMiaWallis]*I am actively looking for non-UK companies to replace the UK ones I used to buy from. The increased cost that I have seen on the likes of Amazon.co.uk means it's not an economical option for me anymore (I'm in the EU). I have moved to amazon.de*

That's of course your choice. Our EU customers are still ordering from us and it's not costing them any more that it was before.[/quote]
Iâ€™m wondering which products you are selling too and how you can manage to not have anything to add vs what we had before 

Mainly because what Iâ€™ve heard so far from people in the eu is the opposite

Title: Tax on goods from EU surely not correct?
Message:
*I am actively looking for non-UK companies to replace the UK ones I used to buy from. The increased cost that I have seen on the likes of Amazon.co.uk means it's not an economical option for me anymore (I'm in the EU). I have moved to amazon.de*

That's of course your choice. Our EU customers are still ordering from us and it's not costing them any more that it was before.

Title: Tax on goods from EU surely not correct?
Message:
[quote MrsMiaWallis]*However, there is nothing to stop them charging UK customers the same price as the VAT inclusive price they charge domestic EU customers. More profit*

This is true but unlikely. I've just ordered from Sweden. No tax on item, so 20% cheaper then tax payable on entry into UK. 

Most businesses will sort it if they want to carry on selling to UK.

We are still selling happily to the EU.[/quote]
I guess it depends on the increased cost of doing business with the UK combined with profit margins and volume of sales.

A smaller company is likely to charge more for goods shipped to the UK as they have smaller volumes, possibly smaller profit margins and the increased costs are a larger percentage of their margins.

I am actively looking for non-UK companies to replace the UK ones I used to buy from. The increased cost that I have seen on the likes of Amazon.co.uk means it's not an economical option for me anymore (I'm in the EU). I have moved to amazon.de.

Title: Tax on goods from EU surely not correct?
Message:
[quote Clavinova]*OchonAgusOchonO*
*I didn't order from Amazon*

Oh, ok - I assumed you had because of your previous post;

^The increased cost that I have seen on the likes of Amazon.co.uk means it's not an economical option for me anymore (I'm in the EU). I have moved to amazon.de.^

*I ordered something from amazon in november. Checked the price on it today and it's dearer by â‚¬6.23.*

I wouldn't necessarily expect a price listed on Amazon in November to be the same in January in any case - Amazon had Black Friday deals in November. Is the same item listed on amazon.de? What are the delivery costs from Germany to Ireland?[/quote]
It was not reduced in the black friday sales and no, the exact same item isn't available on .de.

The last item I ordered from .de was â‚¬7.71 delivery. I just checked both .de and .co.uk for to compare costs.

It is â‚¬26.95 plus â‚¬7.71 delivery from .de, so â‚¬34.66. It is â‚¬38.83 with free delivery on .co.uk.

Title: Tax on goods from EU surely not correct?
Message:

Title: What should we all be taking, vitamin D3, anything else?
Message:
You're very welcome *Janus* and thank you for your lovely well wishes for DH. 
I highly recommend Solgar vitamin D3 4000iu (if you can find 5000iu online, even better but the 4000 is plenty). I get mine from Amazon. 

For the kids, I get this vitamin D: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B0082A7GUM/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

Title: Condensation
Message:
Definitely a dehumidifier. It'll make the washing dry more quickly too. We use this one:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00474K8SY/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_JV15Fb889HYA6?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

I also keep the window open when cooking. If you're boiling something it releases loads of steam into your house.
Open any trickle vents on your windows.

Title: Exciting books for a beginning reader
Message:
My kids both really liked the Usborne Farmyard tales books. Each page has a top line in bigger text is for the child to read and the bottom few lines in smaller text are for the adult. The stories are much better than in a beginner reader because the adult words can add a lot more story. The DC seem to really like the idea of something that is supposed to be a joint effort. When the get better at reading, you can swap around who reads the adult / child words.

You can buy a hardback book with all 20 stories in [[https://smile.[[amazon.co.uk/dp/1409562921/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_Xxt0Fb0NYKM9V?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/dp/1409562921/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_Xxt0Fb0NYKM9V]]]] or get them individually.

If your DD turns out to like it (or she's very into princesses as an alternative) Usborne also do a book of princess stories and a book of fairytales with adult / child words.

Title: 8 week old baby sleep help
Message:
Yes it will get better and he's so little still, these days won't last forever.

Sone things you could try are sticking him in a sling when you want him to have a nap.  The warmth and comfort of you might help him to nod off.

Have you tried putting a T-shirt that DH has worn as the sheet in his cot instead of one if your T-shirt's.  This helps some babies.

What white noise have you tried too?

As for night, we ended up sleeping with both of ours as it was the only way we could get some sleep.  They are both happy and content teens now, it really doesn't last forever.

The [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/No-Cry-Nap-Solution-Guaranteed-Problems/dp/007159695X No Cry Nap Solution]] might help too [thanks]

Title: Non fiction recommendations please
Message:
I really loved the 3 sets of wartime diaries published via the Mass Observation project - Our Hidden Lives, We Are At War and Private Battles, collated by Simon Garfield. They cover half a dozen different diarists during the war, and flip back and forth between the same few people.  You get a real sense of the people as they talk about what they had for dinner, what Churchill said on the radio, what they're buying their granny for Christmas, and how Mrs so and so from down the road died in an air raid the other day... 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Our-Hidden-Lives-Remarkable-Diaries/dp/0091897335?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Another non fiction book I love is The Children's Blizzard by David Laskin. It's a gripping account of one blizzard in the American Midwest in the winter of 1888.
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Childrens-Blizzard-David-Laskin/dp/0060520760?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Thread 26 - the one with the last minute panic buys
Message:
On the chess set front, I played chess for my country and as a child and tend not to like any of the fancy chess sets. Iâ€™d recommend a tournament chess set which is regulation size and very simply designed. Itâ€™s the generic set that would be used by a lot of clubs teaching chess and in tournaments. Something like this [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Andux-Pieces-Rollable-QPXQ-01-42x42cm/dp/B078XT7YD1/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?dchild=1&smid=AI0DEM54106VN&psc=1&keywords=Tournament+Chess+Set&spLa=ZW5jcnlwdGVkUXVhbGlmaWVyPUEyU0g4VE05MzFLUE5RJmVuY3J5cHRlZElkPUEwMjQwMzg0U1NGMkk5OU5YOUhGJmVuY3J5cHRlZEFkSWQ9QTA4ODUwMjgxMlJTWVk3NUQ5VlAyJndpZGdldE5hbWU9c3BfYXRmJmFjdGlvbj1jbGlja1JlZGlyZWN0JmRvTm90TG9nQ2xpY2s9dHJ1ZQ==&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607848554&sr=8-1-spons]]
It also has the notation which is useful and can also be bought with a harder folding board. The pieces are lovely and big and distinguishable!

Title: C25k get your encouragement here.
Message:
*Cavagirl* I bought [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B08DG38BW7/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 these ones]] but tbh I could have bought any of about 10 similar offerings on amazon.  Theyâ€™re pretty good, though they did lose connection on a run the other day when it was raining and I had my phone in my leggings pocket.   If you want in ear ones Iâ€™d suggest looking for ones that look quite small, DH has some that I initially thought Iâ€™d borrow but turns out they were too big for my ears! 

I keep my phone either in pocket on the side of leggings (iuga ones from amazon), or in a very sexy bumbag thingy that DH got given as a work freebie. 

*Misandry* nooo! I am hoping I will grow to love running, otherwise I know I wonâ€™t keep it up once the c25k finishes.

Title: Gaming Headphones Recommendation Please
Message:
My two had turtle beach ones. They have this design flaw where they break at the joint where the headband part goes into the ear pieces. I looked around for others that looked sturdier and got a couple of these at Christmas. NB cordless best apparently! I also paid for warranties for 2 year accidental damage.

Title: Was Mandela a terrorist or a freedom fighter?
Message:
Sash - itâ€™s not ignorant for a South African person not to know specific details about life in NI some years ago.

OP, Cinderella - my ancestors were just getting on with farming. They were English tenant farmers. Rather offensive to accuse them of â€˜ stealing land that did not belong to them, out of sheer greed and a ridiculous sense of higher standing. Making those they deemed inferior homeless, poor, starving and eventually killing them.â€™ What ridiculous hyperbole, and bizzare assumptions. They were paying rent to make a modest living out of growing and selling food. 

I have realised that I donâ€™t know much Irish history other than in relation the England / UK though, so have ordered [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Brief-History-Ireland-Histories/dp/1849014396/ref=mp_s_a_1_9?dchild=1&keywords=History+of+Ireland&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609684316&sr=8-9#mediamatrixmobile_secondary_view_div_1609684374918]] any other recommendations (not too Â£) though.

Title: Going round and round trying to figure out best breed for us (family dog)...
Message:
A book that may help you is Meet Your Dog by Kim Brophy [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B07BTL8XVH/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&btkr=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21 kindle edition]]


Not the cheapest book on the market but it discusses dogs by types eg toy breeds, working breeds, bull breeds etc.

It explains the motor patters of the dogs and what you can expect living with each typf of dog.

Of course there will be exceptions but it does discuss the hard wired behaviours and reinforcers of the dogs.

Title: To really struggle with job interviews
Message: I used to be exactly the same as you OP Iâ€™d just find myself panicking so much Iâ€™d go off on rambling tangents and then forget the question [blush] What worked for me was ensuring I had a list of succinct examples that illustrated the skills each likely question required and then rehearsing them over and over until they stuck in my brain. This book was also invaluable - Why You?: 101 Interview Questions You'll Never Fear Again [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00L3SYV3A/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_qGn1FbZX1YW5G?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: What to eat during hotel stay
Message: Hey OP Iâ€™ve had similar issues. My son has extensive allergies and we had to stay in a hotel without cooking facilities. I took a hot plate (https://www.[[amazon.co.uk/Duronic-Table-Top-Stainless-Steel-Electric-Simmering/dp/B0013HI1JQ/ref=mp_s_a_1_3?dchild=1&s=kitchen-appliances&keywords=electric+Hot+Plates&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1610828160&sr=1-3) amazon.co.uk/Duronic-Table-Top-Stainless-Steel-Electric-Simmering/dp/B0013HI1JQ/ref=mp_s_a_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=electric+Hot+Plates&qid=1610828160&s=kitchen-appliances&sr=1-3)]] and a little saucepan. If she can have rice or pasta, you can boil these easily and buy salads and add to it, you can boil egg, and buy cold cooked meat in supermarkets. Remember to take epipen if she has one. Donâ€™t forget plates and cutlery. Also ask the landlord if you can go into your house maybe once or twice a day to access your fridge and microwave. Maybe they can move it to a different part of you flat like the living room or bedroom. Good luck!

Title: Times Tables apps/games for secondary
Message:
The best times tables resource I ever found was this by Graham Woodward. It uses learning by movement and helps them to see times tables as a puzzle / understand the relationsips between the answers etc. Its hard to explain but there is a video on the website. I got my children to spend 10mins on this each day (I also bought the divided by pack) and within 12 weeks my twins knew all their times tables up to 12 x 12 off by heart. This was in year 3. Building on this knowledge within 6 months my son knew all his times tables up to 20 x 20 off by heart and my daughter up to 18 x 18. In year 3 they were at the top of the school. Not because they were maths genuises but because they had a good grounding in understanding how to quickly work out the answers.
[[http://www.ko-box.com/knowyourtimestables.html]]

We also used this game. Its like snakes and ladders but it can be made harder for adults. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00FGPUHS4/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

And I also bought this photocopable book and got my twins to do a page each day of practise. Mine were still in grade 3 when they did this and it only took them a few minutes so won't take them too long each day.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/1505361729/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]

Title: I've messed up haven't I â˜¹ï¸
Message:
I'm so sorry for your loss.

I know it doesn't sound very comforting at the moment, but if he's holding it together in school and exploding at home, that's a huge message to you that he feels safe and secure enough with you to express his feelings. 

I agree with people who have said specific bereavement counselling will help.

The book 'The Explosive Child' by Dr. Ross Greene may also give you some strategies.
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Explosive-Child-Understanding-Frustrated-Chronically/dp/0062270451/ref=pd_sbs_14_1/257-8584892-2476326?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Thread 25 - the one where WE GOT TO MAGIC THREAD 25!

Title: What to get 18month old...
Message:
If you can go up a few pounds, I'd say these: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/infinitoo-Magnetic-Building-Construction-Edutainment/dp/B07C87XSD8/ref=sr_1_11?dchild=1&keywords=mag+shapes&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607817303&sr=8-11]]

If you shop around I bet you can find a smaller set for closer to ten - I just linked to give an idea. My DD had these and adored them, and they are a toy that lasts really well and is good for quite a wide age range, so they would be good for your friend's eco principles.

Alternatively, maybe packs of seeds for him to plant? Depends on him/his mother - if she won't thank you for another job there's no point! But my brother gave DD packs of seeds one Christmas when she was rising two, and she was delighted and did understand that what grew was 'hers'. 

Or a bird box/bird feeder? Same caveats about not giving the parents another job apply, but if they might like it, it could be put up by his window/somewhere he can see, so he can feel it's 'his'?

Title: Spider plant going brown at tips.
Message:
I bought soil moisture meter to gauge when to water my house plants (and outdoor plants too).  Since using this I've discovered my own judgement is often incorrect.  My plants look much healthier now.

Mine is like this:  [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/XLUX-Soil-Moisture-Sensor-Meter/dp/B014MJ8J2U/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&keywords=soil+moisture&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1607682548&sr=8-3]]

Title: What is going to get hair off the carpets?
Message:
I've got one of the cheap triangular metal lint removers (from Amazon) and that's great for getting hair and fluff off anything! I wouldn't use it on delicate fabrics, but it's been fine on my carpets.

Not a quick job though as it's not very big.

Mine is something like [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/RosewineC-Portable-Remover-Clothes-Restores/dp/B08BC78P5H/ref=asc_df_B08BC78P5H/?hvlocphy=9046348&hvlocphy=9046348&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvnetw=g&hvadid=459061500658&hvadid=459061500658&hvpone&hvpone&hvlocint&hvlocint&ref&hvpos&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-944792477225&hvtargid=pla-944792477225&hvrand=440540967337295610&hvrand=440540967337295610&adgrpid=106107184023 this]] .

Title: Has anyone successfully dyed Dr Martens?
Message:
This place does many many colours of polish. If you got a shade darker than you currently have, something like the dark aubergine, or the mahogany, that would probably do it! 
I've used hot pink/fuscia on a pair of shoes, worried about matching the colour up, but it was intense enough to just cover everything beneath it- all the salt and water stains etc. It was a very soft, absorbent leather, though.

https://www.amazon.co.uk/TRG-One-Unisex-Adult-Treatments-Polishes/dp/B00JOHZ1IQ

Title: Indoor interactive puzzles /toys for dog
Message:
We started my old boy off on a snuffle mat, then when he got the hang of that bought a kong wobbler and 6 months on heâ€™s doing a bit of scent work like hiding treats under yoghurt pots and making parcels out of toilet roll inners for him to find in the house.  Iâ€™ve bought him [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00140OVA0/ref=twister_B08PF3X46G?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21 this]]  brain training puzzles Christmas from a recommendation.  Itâ€™s double sided so two for the price of one.  

Doing the brain games is helping him in terms of brain stimulation, but also his arthritis, as he has to move and stretch to get the treats out.

Have a look at the Nina Ottosson puzzles.  There are three or possibly four ability levels and if you look them up on Amazon, it will come up with a variety of other brands and puzzles as suggestions as well.

Title: Any recommendations for me to read to ds (nearly 10)
Message:
Hello elliejjtiny, I have just released a middle-grade portal fantasy entitled The Puddle People. It's available as an eBook for 77p or paperback for Â£5. It's free if you have Kindle Unlimited. I'll post the blurb here for you.
Eleven-year-old Ethan Myles is having a bad day: His summer holiday has been cancelled, the weird glowing crystal he found in the garden has given him an electric shock, draining him of enjoyment, and his mum is suffering from a terminal illness.
If that wasnâ€™t bad enough, heâ€™s only got minutes to stop a race of strange watery beings, led by evil ice-man, Doctor Freeze, sucking the fun from humanity, leaving the entire human race in the darkness of everlasting misery.
Will Ethan and his nine-year-old sister Amber manage to defeat Doctor Freeze before itâ€™s too late, or will all human pleasure cease to exist?
I do hope DS enjoys it. Regards, Tommy Ellis
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Puddle-People-Ethan-Amber-Worlds-ebook/dp/B08SKJ8XN3/ref=sr_1_10?dchild=1&keywords=the+puddle+people&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1610474713&sr=8-10]]

Title: Dog groomers no longer essential...
Message:
If you are going to trim your dog at home, for heaven sake get round ended curve blade scissors such as [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Wahl-Smartgroom-Grooming-Curved-Scissors/dp/B000YKUK92/ref=sr_1_9?hvlocphy=9045894&hvnetw=g&keywords=curved+dog+grooming+scissors&hvadid=259002103350&qid=1610653687&dchild=1&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI_Jn5tpic7gIVG-vtCh3ZjwUlEAMYAyAAEgIL9PD_BwE&hydadcr=7824_1755559&hvdev=t&hvqmt=e&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=kwd-312137953827&adgrpid=54270761478&hvrand=5271662154069558468&sr=8-9 these]]

And be very very careful round bums - might be better to use baby wipes or soak out any poo crumbs

Title: An actual litter tray question
Message:
[quote NoSensei]You could get a litter locker? Itâ€™s the same as a nappy bin. I use biodegradable bags in the kitchen bin too, itâ€™s fine, sometimes I have to double bag just in case![/quote]
The new world of litter is amazing to me.  So much has changed in 15 years!  I've just ordered a top entry litter tray, which I'm sure never existed when I got my last cat.  A litter locker is also totally new to me!  That's really useful - thank you.  I may just see how we get on but have this as an option.

My old cat only used to eat dry food and this one's on wet food, so I imagine the poo is pretty pongy!  My old cat could clear a room with a fart though! [grin]

I got these poo bags from Amazon [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B006V3OB64/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o01_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 poo bags]] - the reviews that mention cat litter are good, so fingers crossed they won't let out the smell.

Title: My 6yo is not a nice person
Message:
I wouldn't exactly say that your DD is "not a nice person", more she is a child with social skills difficulties. The smile is not insolence (although it is probably the most infuriating thing she could do!) it is a sign of panic and trying to keep control. Yes, I've seen that smile myself (I might even have worn it sometimes [smile])

You're right that pulling her up might not achieve much and punishing her often is likely to send her further along the spiral. One thing to do is to recognise and react positively to every bit of pro-social behaviour - every bit of kindness or politeness or co-operation or obedience - that she achieves when you're around to see it. Because these behaviours are not easy for her. So in addition to getting her to report on kindness, you can help her by noticing them and labelling them for her.

She is showing a mix of troubles. There's a book I like called [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Unwritten-Rules-Friendship-Strategies-Paperback/dp/B00IGYN2O8/ref=pd_lpo_14_img_1/257-7860081-1947415?psc=1&pf_rd_p=7b8e3b03-1439-4489-abd4-4a138cf4eca6&_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_wg=GVKZ4&pf_rd_r=3D2TVSN9Z1Z79W5QXP9M&pd_rd_i=B00IGYN2O8&pd_rd_w=O1IeL&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&refRID=3D2TVSN9Z1Z79W5QXP9MThe&pd_rd_r=5e79538f-8e34-4c61-b9d8-43963aa66f96 Unwritten Ruls of Friendship]] which takes a look at many different kinds of social difficulties that cdifferent children can have. I like it because it gives exercises that you can do to help your child learn these "unwritten rules" of kindness and politeness and develop the positive side of your child's character. Have a look especially at the sections on the Intimidating Child, Born Leader, Pessimistic Child and Sensitive Soul as it sounds as if she has some traits from each of these. 

You might also want to look into communication and de-escalation techniques. Sounds as if you ask her do something, she refuses or is rude, you tell her off, and it all blows up from there and ends in tears and self blame. With some children you can stop trouble before it starts by just not reacting to the first thing she says. Count to 10, then repeat the instruction with the same or fewer words. You might find she just does it (possibly with grumbling but ignore that, you've won). Some kids have a few seconds processing delay and so their first reaction is say "no" to an instruction or request. But given that time to process they are able to listen to what you want and put it on their mental agenda. With my son, I used a lot of "count to three and consequence" - by the time I'd told him exactly what to do and told him the consequence and counted to 3 he had time to figure it out and decide to do it. "Will you do it now or in five minutes?" works for him too, he always says "five minutes" but it is so much calmer than telling him to do it right now.

*My thinking at the mo is that I don't necessarily care what she feels about it (in this scenario) but she absolutely will be polite to other people.*

That may work, good if it does. If it doesn't get better you may need to look into deeper difficulties such as autism-spectrum. Not dealing with change and not being aware she is hurting or offending others or not understanding how what she is saying is hurtful... that could (possibly) be ASC.

Title: Toddler refuses to eat homecooked food or try anything new
Message:
I should have added this one [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Dental-Diet-Surprising-between-Life-Changing/dp/1781809305/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=the+dental+diet&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611650242&sr=8-1]] 

It is nothing new, since Weston Price already highlighted how crocked teeth , narrow palates, didn't exist before industrial food (white flour, sugar and processed oils) and wrote extensively about it in 1930. 

Dr Li's book is very recent and his food suggestions are easier than some of the Weston Price Foundation. 

Refined food is damaging to health in many more ways than one thinks, beyond what a multivitamin can fix. A wrong diet will change the facial features and even the bone structure. 

Cooking is not hard if your DH is determined and understand that his first role is ensuring health. 

He could try making a chicken schnitzel: 
3 plates with in this order
1 plate with flour
1 plate with an egg mixed
1 plate with bread crumbs.

Cut chicken breast into stripes, and put one at the time first in flout, then egg, then breadcrumbs and lay on a plate. Add extra virgin olive oil in a pan, heat it up a bit, and put the chicken to cook until brown. a tiny bit of salt, put two kitchen papers on a plate and put chicken on top to remove excess oil. 
Later, when accepted you can add some parsley to the bread crumbs. 

Industrial food is not plain, far from it, a ton of additives, salt, sugars, and oils are added to make it very tasty. Yet when a parent prepare a vegetable, many won't do much with it and then wonder why a child doesn't like it. Vegetables need to be dressed, seasoned . There is a big difference between a boiled pumpkin cube and roasted pumpkin in the oven with garlic, fresh rosemary, olive oil and coarse salt cooked a quite high temperature. 
However, a  boiled pumpkin to which one adds good quality butter and salt makes a delicious mash. 

It doesn't take much to make vegetables taste nice. 
It isn't difficult to cook. It does take time, but difficult , nope

Title: Toddler refuses to eat homecooked food or try anything new
Message:
I think you and your DH should have a conversation about what you think should be the best diet health wise for your son, what you would like him to eat and accept that both of you have been lazy in that department.
If you really want to change what your son eats, and move away from high processed, highly transformed, artificial and highly palatable food and opt for a diet rich of fresh fruit and vegetables, fresh meat, fresh fish, nutrient (and not additives) rich, you need to accept responsibility and stop making excuses. 

Not knowing how to cook is not a valid argument. Nobody knows how to drive a car before learning to drive. We all learn new things , from how to use a computer, to gaming. 
in 2021, with a zillion YouTube channels dedicated to cooking, blogs, books and so on, if you want learn to cook, you can. Never has it been so easy. 

So, when step 1 (deciding how your son and your family  should eat) is done, step 2 (his eating preferences and habits are your doing) is accepted,  only then can you move to step 3, changing the way he and  you both eat. 

You have shaped your DS's taste buds and gut bacteria towards industrial food, and if you keep that food, while trying to integrate real food, or sneak it, hide it, it will just be a painful-for-all battle, like continue giving cocaine to someone, just less. 

Make home version of the industrial food he is used to eat, and one by one, remove all the others and don't buy them again. Involve him in the buying, cooking of the food. 
Co-habitation of bad and good makes no sense. IF you are determined to do good to your son, educate yourself on real food and the damage of bad. 
Three books to get your started: 
1) First bite [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00PFBLNSC/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_bibl_vppi_i1?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
2) In defence of food 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B002RI99LY/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_bibl_vppi_i1?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] 
3) The science of skinny (this one is a weightloss book, but the first part explain how damaging process food is) [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06XCPNLCQ/ref=dbs_a_def_rwt_bibl_vppi_i1?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]] 

The more you wait , the harder it will be

Title: Gum disease (just been diagnosed)
Message:
I have a full on teeth routine that I do in the shower / bath daily or whenever I remember - if you do it in the bath it doesn't feel like taking special time out for it or a hassle

1) Sonic toothbrush, the lidl one is fine and not expensive, change brush heads regularly (once a month). Use to also gently massage gums after teeth

2) use a tongue scraper daily 

3) get an interspace brush something like this (not an interdental), 
use after brushing to go around the gumline, it is excellent for getting rid of plaque that toothbrushes can't reach. these really are amazing:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Interspace-Toothbrush-Brushes-Orthodontic-Bridges/dp/B01LQUOWEW/ref=asc_df_B01LQUOWEW/?hvlocphy=1006565&linkCode=df0&hvptwo&psc=1&hvnetw=g&hvadid=310843213580&hvpone&hvlocint&hvpos&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl&hvqmt&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&hvtargid=pla-562027560470&hvrand=14470882074380996745]]

4) Use interdental teepee brushes between teeth

5) also floss

6) oil pulling with coconut oil after brushing once every couple of days for a few minutes, making sure to rinse after. It's great at reaching bacteria that may be hiding between teeth or whatever. 

7) I often rub coconut oil into my gums at night, it's antibacterial and good for gum health, and not bad for the teeth either. Will really help!

Best of luck OP! and don't forget to be consistent.  

Good luck! I know all of this sounds excessive but done in the bath or as often as you can it's easy to keep up with it. I don't always do every step every day but as many as I can remember to do, so most are done every other day at the least.

Title: To ask how if I'll  ever get over my miscarriage
Message:
That is what I've read  - 50% at least, and yes, sadly they are mostly abnormalities that are either completely lethal, or are ones which the majority of babies don't survive - like Patau's syndrome for example (trisomy 13) where a few babies are born with the condition but most babies that had it would have already died in the womb. 
If you want to know more, I would recommend [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Miscarriage-What-every-Woman-needs/dp/1409175685/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&crid=2OIR2FLQT55LY&keywords=lesley+regan+miscarriage&sprefix=lesley+regan+misc%2Caps%2C174&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1608473293&sr=8-1 Lesley Regan's book on recurrent miscarriage]] - she goes through all the reasons and in the overwhelming majority of cases it's nothing that anyone could have helped. I hope that is some sort of comfort to you.

Title: Thoughtful gift for muslim friend?
Message:
I wouldn't use th word culture. A lot of culture actually goes against Islam. Just thought I'd point that out as it seems like you're a person open to learning about others. But yes being a Muslim, for many is about the 24/7 identity and not limited to a specific day or time or place. 

Like someone said above, she's a person like anyone else so would like normal everyday things but you noticed she is proud of her faith but I wouldn't advise buying a Qur'an or something as she probably has many. 

I'd get a nice looking book like this 
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Title-Reflections-Pearls-Concise-Comprehensive/dp/0972835857?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
as it's practical too or this one is beautiful but small but that's a bonus too as it means you can carry it around with you:

Title: Please help me sort my skin out
Message:
I have had acne since having my children, my oldest is now 30! Mine is better now I am on the mini pill but I still get acne from time to time on the chin and nose area. I have taken roaccutane twice but the results only lasted a very short length of time and for the side effects it was not worth it. 
I did use the Jan Marini line of products for a couple of years. 
Now I use normal sensitive skin cleansers, rather than anything harsh to clean my face from makeup. Normally Clarins or Nivea. 
I also like anything with glycolic acid in it as it helps sheds the skin cells. 
I had a Murad facial last month and I came out glowing and very little breakout afterwards so I have ordered this
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B0094QRX10/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o03_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]]
I am also using this on a nightly basis
[[https://www.renskincare.com/collections/face/products/ready-steady-glow-daily-aha-tonic]]
Following with a moisturiser 
I have watched a few of the Facebook clarins facial videos and find I am much gentler on my skin now which I do this makes a difference.

Title: Can anyone help me with using Nintendo via Xbox handset and wireless headphones?!
Message:
It sounds complicated because it is.
Basically, the Nintendo switch is plugged into the tv with HDMI lead. 
There's a Mayfair controller adapter [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B079B5KHWQ?ref=ppxpopmobapshare https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B079B5KHWQ?ref=ppxpopmobapshare]]  dongle plugged into the Nintendo switch USB post that allows the x-box controller to be used. 

Elsewhere in the house, there's an Xbox attached to a different tv screen, with the other Xbox controller. In THIS controller it's possible to plug in a wired headset with mic and play with sound.

But with the Xbox controller being used on the Nintendo switch, no wired headphones work. Husband thinks it needs a ^second^ dongle attached to the Nintendo switch, to be able to somehow connect wifi headphones and mic so he can join in with voice chat and not have to yell into the other room.

Does anyone have any experience with this? I don't know what to look for or what it might be called. Or even if it exists. I am keen to get something as all my weekends are spent wishing I could have a slightly quieter house, and this is my life for the next few years. I considered wearing noise cancelling headphones but we also live in a properly where you can hear word for word through the walls, so it's not just about my peace and quiet! 

Any help would be gratefully received.

Title: Lego figure stuck down sink drain
Message:
[quote Chumleymouse]It wonâ€™t dissolve hard plastic !!! Otherwise it would dissolve the plastic pipe and waste trap ðŸ™„. Jesus some people ðŸ©[/quote]
Indeed.
Can you imagine the tens of thousands of people with dissolved waste traps from using Mr Muscle?  Hilarious.

OP, there is a small chance, if there is a lot of hair in the trap, you could pull it up with one of these:

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/FlexiSnake-Drain-Millipede-Hair-Cleaning/dp/B00871R9Z8/ref=sr_1_12?dchild=1&keywords=drain+snake&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1611156705&sr=8-12]]

The handle twists.  If there is hair in there, there is a slim chance it might catch the figure as well.  Other than that it's time to take the trap off.

Title: Would you forget this date? Part 2...
Message:
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM awdb]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM imm]]m_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0399162879/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM t1_yWEeGb9S08RRM]]


I read this book a few years ago just after I got divorced and first encountered the world of online dating. Felt a bit like you, a bit alone and like I'd failed at something. I'm absolutely not a self help type person normally but my friend loved it so I gave it a go. This book is hilarious and quite soothing. It's not preachy or relationship advice, just has some good anecdotes and some interesting ways to think about the world and life. 

It certainly made me much more cheerful about life and being single. Worth a read and I think you'll probably resonate with a lot here.

Title: FFS I need a moisturiser for spotty yet ageing skin
Message:
Hi OP, I think you're me. Same problems, oils, waxes, shea butter, silicones etc are all no-no and I'm using Moisturising Factors too. Have been for a few years, and as a daytime moisturiser it's great but it's also lightweight.

About a month ago I fell down an Amazon rabbit hole and found [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B08BL42BL9/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o04_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 this]] and couldn't resist even though I've got drawers full of other stuff, and I have to say I'm impressed. Much deeper moisturisation with no spots or blackheads.

As I say, I've only been using it a month so I can't report on long term effects, but so far so good.

Title: Air fryer or steam mop
Message:
I agree that steam cleaners  don't last, they also leave my gloss ceramic tiles streaky so I have to buff them with an emop. So I,might as well just clean them with the emop.  But airfryers aren't much good either IMO. They don't make food taste fried at all. It all just tastes baked which make sense because  they are essentially just small fan ovens.  

If it were me I'd abandon both these ideas  and go for one of these. They get incredibly hot and make perfect thin crispy 'Pizza Express' style pizzas in about 2 minutes  (I use tortilla wraps as a base) as well as being excellent for home made flat breads and roasting veg.   Much more fun than an Airfryer. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/G3Ferrari-Delizia-1XP20000-Express-Pizza-Maker/dp/B00KR8LZ3Q/ref=pd_all_pref_1?psc=1&pf_rd_p=0b287dfd-17bb-473b-878d-27964fab82e6&pf_rd_r=Q9FXNQEM3AMB8B0449FA&pd_rd_wg=oK2es&pd_rd_i=B00KR8LZ3Q&pd_rd_w=oqPXl&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&pd_rd_r=314f1eed-d833-493c-ad8f-bd36d7ddf268]]

Title: Ongoing bullying - how do you cope it?
Message:
Sorry you're going through this. I found [[https://www.kidscape.org.uk/]] really useful. We went on the course, my ds found it immensely useful, as did I. This book was good too [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bullybusting-Help-Children-Teasing-Bullying/dp/1876451041?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]].

How old is your son? I was given some good advice - year nine is the peak of nastiness. Things get better year 10 and 11, when they develop some empathy. I kept ds (who had similar issues to your boy) at the same school. Things did get better for him, but I do sometimes wonder whether I should have changed schools.

Title: Bloody outdoor Christmas lights!!!
Message:
A tube sock is a sport sock, usually but not always lacking a defined heel, hence the name. It would lie nicely over your eyes. Or you could buy a sleep mask.
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Tube-Socks/s?k=Tube+Socks&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]


^Bloody Nora, so now the OP should fart about with a DIY sock come sleep mask in order to pacify nobhead neighbours?! How about the neighbours consider that they 'live near other people and deal with it sensibly'? They live in a cul-de-sac - who is possibly going to derive Christmas cheer from lights flashing on and off outside a house at 2am?^

Well yes, 'farting about', as you put it, with easy fixes to the problem would be the practical way of getting the result you want after all. It would require acknowledging that you live in a built up area among other people who want to celebrate a seasonal holiday in a way that really is quite innocuous.  

Depends though - do you want to get off to sleep or do you want to spit nails all night? The choice is entirely yours.
 
My suggestion is to stop being so furious, stop stubbornly refusing to do what you can to get the sleep you claim to need so desperately, unclench, and do whatever is in your power to do to achieve your aim. 

Standing on dubious principle here and insisting on the other guy doing what you demand isn't going to get you a decent night's sleep, is it?

Title: Aibu to hate having my period! San Pro advice needed
Message:
There are other alternatives to tampons other than menstrual cups. I used to use a cup but can't after a prolapse. 
I have had great success with 'soft' tampons - they are effectively a soft sponge and work really well for me. You can get dry or wet ones - the wet ones aren't actually wet, just pre-lubricated so sound like they might work well for you? They are here on Amazon -Beppy Soft Comfort Tampons with Lubricant Lamination - Pack of 8 [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B007Q3KYVO/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_PErYFbKPFA9BN?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
Or there's another alternative called Flex. It's a rubber disc with a flexible 'cup' that goes over your cervix and catches the blood. Same benefits of a cup in that it's not absorbent but the different application worked better for me. 
[[https://flexfits.uk/]]

Worth trying lots of things to see what suits.

Title: Pizza for the BBQ
Message:
DH got a new BBQ over the summer, and I was thinking of getting him some accessories for Xmas. I was thinking of a pizza oven affair, but I don't really know if we can make do with a decent pizza stone straight on the grill, and then lower the lid (it's a Weber gas BBQ), or whether it's much better to have one of the little pizza houses that goes over the top (like this one: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Hacienda-Steel-Pizza-Oven-Black/dp/B07J3GBHJF/ref=psdc_4295702031_t1_B07RRCBQ8Y)?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]].

Don't really need/want to buy a whole separate pizza oven, I think I'd prefer to see if this got any use first. Weber sells pizza stones only, which seems to indicate that would be sufficient, but would love to know what the MN hive brain says!!.

Title: Baby only nurses for 4 minutes awake/ or one letdown
Message:
I'm glad that he's following his curve nicely! 

My advice to you, more than anything is that you need to relax and follow his feeding cue, the reason he doesn't have any is probably because you're offering the breast before he's fully hungry which could be why he's only feeding for a short time, I would also stop the dreamfeed. Maybe you can keep them for nighttime only if you think his volumes were too low throughout the day? 

I know you're worried about your supply, is there any way you could pump in between? I know he doesn't take the bottle right now, but he may in future once he isn't being pressured, and that way you can relax a bit more ?

I hope I'm not coming across as mean or anything! I'm just trying to type this quickly as I've got to get up with the kids :)

Another thing - read this book : (I know it says bottle, but it works for breast too!)

https://www.amazon.co.uk/Your-Babys-Bottle-feeding-Aversion-Solutions/dp/1976164419/ref=nodl_


And join this group on Facebook:

Title: My Dad Has A Dream.
Message:
Hi Mumsnet. My Dad has a dream, that Iâ€™m trying my best as his daughter, to make come true.

When my brother was 13, he suffered a cardiac rest on our landing floor, in the middle of the night. Itâ€™s safe to say this was the most traumatic thing we as a family could have ever experienced. A few years later, and after one miraculous recovery (for which we are so grateful every day), my Dad, a former plumber, decided to pursue a life-long dream of hisâ€¦ to write a book.

Inspired by what had happened, he put pen to paper (or more like fingertips to keyboard), and wrote a novel based on this life experience, and other strange and awful events that had occurred to various members of his family. My Dad wrote this book on his own. My Dad published this book on his own, setting up his own mini publishing company, Trio Publishing (there are 3 of us kidsâ€¦ get it). He did it all himself, and we are so proud of him. He ordered 5,000 copies, of which we, unfortunately, have around 4,900 still left in boxes around our home. Itâ€™s been devastating to see his dream fail, not for lack of quality as those who read the book have said how great they found it, but purely because he has struggled to bring his book, â€˜The Fearâ€™, to the worldâ€™s attention (at 62, social media is not his greatest friend).

Thatâ€™s where I come in. Iâ€™m his 22-year-old daughter, and am trying to harness the power and positivity of social media to get my Dadâ€™s book out there. I thought, where better than Mumsnet? All I hope for is to see my Dad fulfill his dream of becoming a best-selling author. As a Dad whoâ€™s provided me with so much love and support, this is my way of trying to show, to some small degree, what he means to me.

If you feel like supporting a great man, and a (very) small, local business, â€˜The Fearâ€™ by Mark Cunnington  is available on Amazon and at his own website [[www.triopublishing.co.uk]]

Thank you.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Fear-Mark-Cunnington/dp/0953795179?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]
(I'm sorry if this isn't what you guys want to see here, I'm just trying my best. Please don't be angry with me!)


[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Fear-Mark-Cunnington/dp/0953795179?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Opk ovulation tests help- which ones??
Message:
Hmmm not sure if I'm allowed to post a link?! I'll try but it may get deleted. It tells you what day to start based on your cycle length, and you do one test per day til you get a peak. So I actually used 11 tests this cycle! Either these or the connect ones will be the same, just to give you the option! Good luck x

Digital Ovulation Test Kit (OPK) - Clearblue Advanced. Title: Best path for a slope
Message:
gravel in mesh is definitely cheapest.  Putting timbers across at intervals would hold the gravel back, and then you  might be able to have a narrow slope in the timber that you can drive a wheelbarrow through the gap?  

But moving a wheelbarrow over gravel and/or on a steep slope is never easy.  how important is the wheelbarrow?  you might do better to use a step-cart with a garden trug on it.

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Climbing-Folding-Luggage-Transport-Capacity/dp/B07Y68PJSQ?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: What happens when your teenager runs away?
Message:
OP, not sure if anyone on the thread has mentioned Therapeutic Parenting? There are some really great books on it that include what to do if a child runs away with some techniques. It's something a lot of adoptive and foster parents use, but works with all children and can help problem behaviour as well as helping you feel you've got some techniques and are a bit more in control. Apologies if already mentioned, but I know several parents who've found it a helpful resource (inc me) so thought it might be a useful suggestion xxx

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Z-Therapeutic-Parenting-Strategies-Solutions/dp/1785923765?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: Jan '21 Lockdown Low Carb Bootcamp - the Easing-in Week
Message:
*Ratherchilly* I make a "taco bowl" by putting shredded lettuce in a bowl and having all the other stuff on top of that. I suggest looking at the ingredients in a ready made spice mix and then making your own version without the sugar.

*Linda* not everyone gets carb flu, especially if you're keeping up with your electrolytes. It also depends on what your diet was like before going low carb.

*Gillyweed* are you giving in to the cravings or are you able to muscle through? I always crave crisps at my TOTM so I find the salt and vinegar pork scratchings work well as a low carb substitute. If you crave chocolate then would a high cocoa chocolate work instead? I like the Sainsburys 85% one that comes in individual 25g bars. It's too high cocoa for me to overeat but hits that chocolate craving. Otherwise you could just try and fill up on something else that's low carb. I find a bowl of Greek yogurt with some double cream and maybe a few berries (if we're on to Bootcamp Light) is a good cheerer-upper.

*Crackofdoom* it sounds like you need electrolytes. Try adding a squeeze of lemon juice and salt to your water. Or the [[https://www.chainreactioncycles.com/mobile/high5-zero-20-tabs/rp-prod42650 Zero electrolyte tablets]] or the [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00SP31TCW?ref=ppxpopmobapshare electrolyte powder if you want to avoid artificial sweeteners.]].*

*Incurably* you could try dried mushrooms, such as shitaki or porcini or mixed, that you rehydrate with warm water then use both the mushrooms and the water to make up your sauce.

*Patapouf* [[https://seriouslylowcarb.com/collections/seriously-low-carb-food/products/the-low-carb-loaf Seriously Low Carb bread.]]

Title: Flying into 2021 - the Flylady January Thread, all Fledglings welcome!
Message:
Bugger, earlier post has disappeared. Anyway:
*Hills* your description of the situation is masterly - technical, but accessible to the Man On The Clapham Omnibus. Have you thought of a career in politics?

*Zoo* it would be perfectly reasonable to ask the Oven Man to sanitise his hands. If you do it too, he won't notice.

*Sing* hope you can find a way to get DD1 properly online.

I spoke too soon about DD and cursed it. Their English results are still fab, but this afternoon they crashed out of a German lesson with panic attacks and screaming after being asked to actually speak ðŸ˜¢.

Hey ho. I am waiting for the PM to make things worse not better in 6 minutes; and then I am going to hide in my book, which is the wartime diary of a young Primary teacher. She's about the same age as my grandmother (also a primary teacher) would have been at the time, and it's an interesting window on the rural world of the 40s [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/1844088111/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_apa_fabc_X718FbXD8ANJ2?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 here]].

Eveninâ€™ all. Wait no. Morning. Iâ€™m confused ðŸ˜‚ insomnia hit big time last night, I spent some time catching up on several pages of the thread, and then finally ordered a weighted blanket as theyâ€™re supposed to help with such things. *Zoo* might that be worth a try for you and/or non sleeping zookids? They are much cheaper on Amazon now - I got the heaviest (king size) for Â£32 and there are thousands of good reviews, so I figured Iâ€™d take the chance on this one

Really hope this lockdown isnâ€™t a long one, I know it could be an awful lot worse but Iâ€™m gutted that I finally started teaching again and now I have to stop. 

Must get out of the house for exercise instead today! I finally decided on layout for my exercise tracker ðŸ˜‚ and filled in the walks Iâ€™ve done so far. 

Also need to:

Title: Maternity legging recommendations
Message:
Sorry to go against the flow but I ordered Love Leggings maternity leggings based on recommendations from Mumsnet and returned them straight away. I loved their 7/8 non-maternity gym/yoga legginings though and have kept those for after the pregnancy. [grin] I am also used to my gym leggings and wearing high-waisted leggings, that are good quality, squat-proof and where you feel "supported" but not restricted in any way. 

I think leggings are such a personal taste. I'm sorry to report that, in my experience, Love Leggings ones are nothing like what you describe you are after. Yes, they are super soft and comfortable. The fabric is thick but more similar to sweatpant fabric with fleecey lining on the inside. But they are most definitely not "structured", will mark every single tiny bump on your skin and don't offer any support whatsoever. They'd be amazing for lounging on the sofa or sleeping in on a very cold night but that's not what i was after. Also, I'm guessing you're probably a good few weeks away from your bump being generous enough to fill the Love Leggings ones.

To be honest, I've pretty much given up on maternity leggings and have decided instead to just get high-waist leggings in a bigger size that will presumably see e through the postpartum months as well. Many people swear by Lululemon Aligns to take them through the pregnancy and see to fit the bump amazingly well. Apparently they are super comfortable and stretch well over the bump. I didn't want to spend on Lululemon so I've gone with my favourite dupes that you can get from Amazon. I'm currently 26 weeks and very comfortable wearing these ones: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B083JRHBYF/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]] Black ones seem to be out of stock currently though. I got them at 14 weeks one size bigger than my normal size and I still have room to grow. They're brilliant for the bump as there is a wide waist panel which I find supportive but not restrictive and there is no elastic at the top. I've been using my pre-pregnancy leggings from the same brand until now and only now started feeling like I need extra space. My other recommendation are these leggings: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B0813G9HK3/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8]] I've just ordered a bigger size to serve as "maternity" leggings. Hope it helps! Good luck with the search [smile]

Title: Why am I so heavy?
Message: I don't think you sound particularly heavy, but if you *feel* it, that's a different matter. It could be hormone-related â€“ if you're mid-40s, you may well be perimenopausal. Plus HIIT exercise every day will stress your body and floods it with insulin and cortisol, preventing you from burning fat effectively. You might need to do less and have more rest days for better results. I can recommend this [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/1910056537/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o00_s00?psc=1&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&ie=UTF8 book]] called It's Not You, It's Your Hormones: The Essential Guide for Women Over 40 to Fight Fat, Fatigue and Hormone Havoc by Nicki Williams. Reading it was like a lightbulb going off â€“ I just thought I was rubbish at dieting and resigned to be fat in middle age (I'm 48) but this has made me completely rethink my approach to my health.

Title: Help with waking up teenager
Message:
Ds1 tried this device and didn't like it but gets out of bed very easily. Ds2 loves it, a sunrise alarm clock.  

I actually have Ds1's for myself but I will admit to putting a yellow acetate sheet over it as it starts off with a lovely glow but then becomes interrogation white [grin] the closer you get to the alarm time. 

I bought a pack of coloured acetate or overlays and tried different ones to see what I liked. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Crosse-Technology-Soluna-Light-Options/dp/B07YD5Q76H?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 this is mine]] but I got it from Costco so it was about Â£24. Obviously there are plenty of others on the market. 

It just slowly increases the light levels in the room which may help rouse him from a deeper sleep. What time does he go to bed though? Mine go very early and get up very early too.

Title: what to do the day after a binge?
Message:
Get it off of amazon. Theyâ€™ll only see a purchase, not what it was. And who gives a crap if they see the book? Youâ€™re taking control of your mental and physical health. Thatâ€™s a positive. 

Sounds like your mum should read it too. 

P.s I have binge eating disorder. I know exactly what youâ€™re going through. And the answer to stop the weight gain and the bingeing truly is to stop restricting yourself. 

Once I did that, I lost weight naturally, eating full fat mayo, McDonaldâ€™s and drinking full fat coke. The difference was I wasnâ€™t bingeing any more. 

[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Have-Your-Cake-Skinny-Jeans/dp/0988954419/ref=mp_s_a_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=thin+side+out+josie+spinardi&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1610401887&sr=8-1]]

Good luck

Title: Addicted to fizzy juice, want to stop. Has anyone done it?
Message:
Your OP is right, you have an addiction

Sugar is no different to any other addictive substances like nicotine.  And it is as harmful.

I would recommend cold turkey.  You will feel ill for at least a week, maybe 2.  But you need to break the addiction.

A great book about this to motivate you is here: [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Case-Against-Sugar-Gary-Taubes/dp/0307701646?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Or a Video version here:  [[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E0QvRreX7Gk]]

If you quit sugar, you will lose weight. 

Good luck.  Don't under estimate the harm that you are doing to yourself and also how hard it will be to quit....but it's 2 weeks max of pain for much improved health, energy and wellbeing

Title: And it all started with...
Message:
[quote havecourage8bekind]Hey everyone, we are back at the house now. He was an arse to me and his sister had to tell him to leave it! We stayed for a while after he dropped them off, and then we were on the lookout for his car while driving back. Will get more information about drop off and pick up safety advice tomorrow when they call me back from EDN. House is upside down currently as we are decorating the Christmas tree and I couldn't be any happier! I cried earlier because DD (7) said to me "mummy, I finally feel settled" well, that just broke me!! [/quote]
Oh op, thatâ€™s so tough about your DD saying that BUT on the other hand, thatâ€™s also what people meant about this just being a short season. I know itâ€™s been awful and so, so stressful, but itâ€™s gone pretty quickly. I know someone else mentioned checking your children for trackers but... Iâ€™m afraid I agree. The more you refuse him the address, the crazier heâ€™s going to become. Please, please do check the children for something like new wristwatches, new apps on their phones or iPads if they have anything like that, even anywhere he could place something as small as a Tile, which can track (Iâ€™ve attached a picture) anything: 
https://www.[[amazon.co.uk/Tile-Mate-Item-Finder-Pack/dp/B07W9BBCTB?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/Tile-Mate-Item-Finder-Pack/dp/B07W9BBCTB?]]
If heâ€™s vindictive enough to do things like putting your â€œtoysâ€ in the garage, then who knows what his next move is.

Title: Nonfiction book on creepy crawlies
Message: I don't particularly like insects but my son was obsessed with them - so I wrote this little book for kids aged 8+ which has just been published, it's got fascinating facts about a few creatures (verified by entomologists) and the drawings are my kid's when he was aged 3 -15. I'm trying to highlight the importance of insects in the food chain. Imagine the state of the countryside if there were no dung beetles for starters. It is called Goggas: A collection of captivating creepy crawlies and is on Amazon. Here's a link [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B08P3PC675?tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

Title: The Brexit Arms
Message:
*
I agree you make some good points about increasing immigration from the developing world (personally I would prefer our efforts went into making  the developing world a better place to live but hay ho) many British asians voted Leave (very shrewdly) with this in mind. I think you are hopeless naive thinking Brexit will improve the lives of minorities in the UK.  I would suggest you follow some Vote Leave groups on the internet to get a measure of what a great number of Leave voters think. Leave EU is a good starting point. I would also recommend two books for you.

[[https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.waterstones.com/book/the-sovereign-individual-mastering-the-transition-to-the-information-age/james-dale-davidson/william-rees-mogg/9780684832722&ved=2ahUKEwjCkuvJx__tAhUFoVwKHXp3BNoQFjAKegQIFBAB&usg=AOvVaw0tCY0W1wnV59diOsSbnMzM]]


[[https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.[[amazon.co.uk/Britannia-Unchained-Global-Lessons-Prosperity/dp/1137032235&ved=2ahUKEwjFw_Srx__tAhW7QEEAHQlYB0UQFjAJegQIFhAB&usg=AOvVaw0mA0ncaygQtzOJBbbMj8UN?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 amazon.co.uk/Britannia-Unchained-Global-Lessons-Prosperity/dp/1137032235&ved=2ahUKEwjFw_Srx__tAhW7QEEAHQlYB0UQFjAJegQIFhAB&usg=AOvVaw0mA0ncaygQtzOJBbbMj8UN]]]]

Title: The Brexit Arms
Message:
All this talk of "sovereignty" and "taking back control" comes from the advertising campaign slogans dreamed up by Dominic Cummings during the referendum campaign.

I have to hand it to Cummings, he conducted a masterful campaign, used up to date advertising methods and cutting edge technology to infiltrate and influence people's opinions and views. The Remain campaign was very amateurish by comparison.

Brexit, to me, is testament to the power of clever advertising. There was, of course, no control to be taken back, it was merely a slogan. But people latched onto it. They wanted something to change and saw leaving the EU as way of making change come about. Change is indeed coming, but probably not any sort of beneficial change for the vast majority of people. 

If you haven't seen it yet, I recommend [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/video/detail/B07MC4NCD6/ref=atv_dp_share_cu_r?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Brexit: the Uncivil War]]

Title: Best bargain moisturiser?
Message:
I use layers: first pat on [[https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/KIKUMASAMUNE-High-Moist-Toner-Skin-Care-Lotion-500-ml-amino-Ceramide-Arbutin/173940336317?epid=710167909&hash=item287fa6e6bd:g:84UAAOSw9sBdDJMO this one]], let it dry a bit, then [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Hadalabo-Institute-Gokujun-hyaluronic-solution/dp/B013HHJV0C/ref=sr_1_3?dchild=1&crid=QH3B0RRRGCKA&keywords=hada+labo+gold+hyaluronic+acid&sprefix=hadolabo+gold%2Caps%2C169&tag=mumsnetforu03-21&qid=1609268818&sr=8-3 this one]]. Let that dry then top them off with Neutrogena Hydro Boost Gel Cream. 

The two lotions are expensive to start but you use so little they last for months. The Neutrogena's often on offer at Boots, Superdrug or supermarkets. It's another (cheaper) version of Clinique Moisture Surge. Neutrogena is part of the same group as Clinique. 

My face feels really comfortable, never tight and itchy as it sometimes used to be with just moisturiser.

 - the pizza stone works well, but not noticeably better than this, which is a lot less work:

*Eggy*, here people with a lot of shopping will often offer to let someone with only a few items go first, but I've never heard anyone asking.  Pleading looks, certainly, but not directly asking.  In New York, pushing in can be risky.  Perhaps that's why it happens so seldom.

Title: Repairing freezer drawer
Message:
Last sumner I repaired a broken  greenhouse glass panel with some Ultimate Duck tape, and my god it is superb. After all the bad wet weather and the lovely summer we had it it still stuck fast! It might be worth a try. 

Duck Tape 222150 Ultimate Cloth Tape Clear 50mm x 20m. The ultimate high strength waterproof gaffer and duct adhesive cloth repair tape [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T sw]]w_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T r]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T cp]]p_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T api]][[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T fabc]]c_[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0051HEDNW/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_fabc_fJH9Fb9NTPD3T fJH9Fb9NTPD3T]]

A friend fixed his ripped soft top rear clear car window with the Gorilla type clear tape which did amazingly well too.

Title: Please could you advise on ddâ€™s Afro hair during lockdown
Message:
*Starseeking* makes a good point. Black Women are too often seen as 'The Help' it's tiring & tiresome.

*Alakazam8* I guessed you weren't Black. I don't normally reply on posts from non-Black women as there tends to be a bs agenda. You were focused on solely on wanting to manage your daughter's hair well and didn't go on about anything else alongside (as too often happens) so it felt ok to reply.

Shea Butter can be heavy on the hair

Mango Butter
[[www.freshskin.co.uk]] 

Try it, you'll notice the difference. 

Or just use a light coconut oil or castor oil pomade. Something like this
[[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0030F4TZO/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_imm_t1_WkGeGbWF4DPRD?psc=1&_encoding=UTF8&tag=mumsnetforu03-21]]

With YouTube tutorials, don't look at long ones where they do a whole bunch of talking. Pick 3 short clips (including a simple Cane Row one) that get straight to the point.

Title: Hardwearing slippers
Message:
My feet are terrible on slippers. I'm lucky if they last 6 months. Doesn't help that I haven't been to a chiropodist in over a year now. I can't wear socks. I hate wearing them inside, whereas I can kick slippers off when I sit down. 

All I want is a supported foot as I have PF (plantar fasciitis) and a nice lining to keep the tootsies warm. I have some lovely ones from Amazon atm but the sole lining has already started to wear out. [[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppx]][[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 yo]]o_[[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 dt]][[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 b]]b_[[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 search]][[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 asin]]n_[[https://smile.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B076F45RSK/ref=ppxyodtbsearchasintitle?ie=UTF8&psc=1 title?ie=UTF8&psc=1]]

Title: Building confidence in my teenage daughter
Message:
So sorry you're going through this OP.If it's any consolation we had a very similar episode with our DD last academic year and the first we knew was when we getting numerous calls from teachers saying that she had failed to hand in her homework again.

She's managed to turn it around and her recent parents evening, by telephone, was glowing.

If she enjoyed drama, are they doing anything online?  If Rangers isn't running would she be interested in Explorers?  It depends on the group by DS' is about 50/50 boys and girls and they're doing online at the moment.

If she is quiet, have either of you read [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Quiet-Power-Introverts-World-Talking/dp/0141029196/ref=ascdf0141029196/?tag=googshopuk-21&linkCode=df0&hvadid=310973726618&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=3251988878984516454&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=m&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=1006886&hvtargid=pla-448425243075&psc=1&th=1&psc=1 Quiet]]?  My DN sounds very similar to your DD and they found it helpful [thanks]

Title: Anyone installed an induction hob after gas and regretted it?
Message:
[quote earsup]We had one in a holiday rental flat in portugal a few years ago....no instructions, found some tips on youtube but just couldnt get used to it...gave up....ate out !!...it may have been faulty....rings kept going from orange to off ...do they only work once the pan is on the ring...??...[/quote]
 That doesn't sound like an induction hob, they don't light up, they stay black. Could it have been a halogen hob? They too are flat glass but a totally different way to cook and those rings do light up. 

 we were very unsure about it before we did it so we bought a 2 ring portable induction hob and cooked with it for a month before making the decision. We were having a kitchen extension built so knew we would need something to cook on in the meantime. Ours is an Andrew James one but this is very similar [[https://www.amazon.co.uk/VonShef-Induction-Portable-Ceramic-Electric/dp/B0725FT8L8?tag=mumsnetforu03-21 Von Chef]] 

We have had our beautiful induction hob 9 years now, we have never had any issues with it. It was Â£850 at the time we bought it but you can combine cooking zone as we have a large Circulon saute pan that was too big for one cooking zone. Ours still looks brand new. It is a DiDietrich. 

Boils fast, very controllable, easy for the children to lift a pasta pot with hot handles and me not stress about them setting the oven gloves on fire on a gas flame. For the portable one, we have used it outside too in summer.
